Maniwaki, Que.,
June 18, 1950.

Dear Father,

I noticed the advertisement for teachers in the Canada Government Circulars, which interested me immensely. Please send me all the particulars regarding qualifications and the salary schedule.

I am interested mostly in Northwestern Ontario. Would you please inform me of the locations there?

I was in the Jesuit Seminary at Kemptville, Ontario for a year and a half. Teaching is work in which I am interested.

Respectfully yours,

William Ryan.

Roman Catholic Teachers,

June 26, 1950.

Mrs. Ella Grace,
1952 - 6th Avenue East,
Owen Sound, Ontario.

Dear Mrs. Grace:

I have for answer your letter of recent date and wish to advise that most of the schools in the Bruce Peninsula area are for Protestant teachers. We have a number of Catholic schools but these have practically all been filled by now. I note that you hold a second class certificate and have had no experience.

We have a vacancy for a married couple at the Arcola Indian Day School situated on the main C.N.R. line about 12 miles from Nakina, Ontario. It is located in a former Hudson's Bay post with the classroom downstairs and the teacher's quarters upstairs. There is no electricity and no running water. Please write if you are interested in any further details. It is unfortunate that you do not possess a First Class Teaching Certificate and therefore we can only offer you a starting salary of $156.00 a teaching month.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, June 21, 1950.

Your Ref. 1-1-LX (E)

Dear Mr. Neary,

I first want to apologise for the delay in replying to your letter of the 23rd ultimo. The reason for this is that I am at present preparing my accounts for Audit and have, therefore, little leisure for my own affairs.

Thank you for forwarding application form for employment as an Indian Day School Teacher. Before completing this document, I wondered if I might have your further advice. I think I pointed out in my letter to Reverend Father Scheffer that I had not actually held any official teaching appointment and because of this I feel that you may not consider my case. It is true that I have taken charge of a class in the absence of a teacher at College on several occasions, and I have from time to time taught English and Latin grammar privately together with some commercial subjects, but I cannot answer question LV to the extent that you may require. It must be some years since I attended any summer schools in England, and I just cannot submit any Inspector's reports. I have always had the desire to teach, but circumstances have not been in my favour. The possibility of being able to teach in the Indian Schools strongly appeals to me, especially as there is the spirit of Missionary work in this field. If you will consider these points together with the facts I have stated in my letter to Reverend Father Scheffer and let me know whether I may be considered a suitable candidate for this work, I will be most grateful. For my part I know I would be a happy and successful teacher, yet I realise that you have certain standards, and because of this, I am very reluctant to waste your time if I am unable to fulfil the required conditions.

With renewed thanks.

I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Bernard Callaghan

June 10th, 1950

The Very Reverend Philip Scheffer, O. M. I.,
340, Provenchel Avenue,
St. Boniface,
Manitoba.

Dear Very Reverend Father Provincial,

Having read your advertisement in today's issue of The Ensign for Teachers for Indian Schools, I am interested in this vocational work and wish to offer myself as a candidate.

For your guidance I beg to submit the following brief outline of my background and education.

After leaving school I continued studies in the field of commerce and was awarded certificates in Accounts and other commercial subjects under the Institutes of Lancashire and Cheshire, England. In 1928, feeling I had a call to the Religious life, I commenced a course of private studies in preparation, and in 1929 was accepted as a student by the Salesian Congregation, first at their Missionary College at St. Rileigh, Cheshire, and finally at Pallaskenny, Co. Limerick, Ireland. I have followed a course of studies for the teaching profession, for all Salesians (or Sons of John Bosco, as they are now called) usually serve for three years after completing their studies in Philosophy. In 1932 I found I was unable to embrace the Religious State, and returning home, entered business once again and took up voluntary social work in the Salford Diocese.

I feel I ought to give some further details of my family. I lost my mother in 1935, and my father is still living, aged 84. All my family are excellent practicing Catholics. I have four brothers; the eldest a prominent member of S.V.P. in the Manchester Council of the Salford Diocese, another elder brother in Stockport, Cheshire, and yet another elder brother in Brazil - Rio de Janeiro. My youngest brother is Reverend Brother Serenus of the De La Salle Brothers and he is Sub-Director of the Catholic Grammar School, St. Helena, Lancashire in the Archdiocese of Liverpool. I have two sisters, both of whom are married and reside in the vicinity of Stockport, Cheshire.

I have with me, testimonials from the Rector of the Salesian Missionary College, Pallaskenny, Reverend Brother Columba of the De La Salle Congregation who is Headmaster of the Salford Diocesan Training College for Catholic Teachers, Hopwood Hall, Middleton, Lancashire. My family is well known to the present Bishop of Salford, The Rt. Reverend Msgr. H. V. Marshall. I also have in my possession a personal recommendation from the Grand
The Very Reverend Philip Scheffer, O.M.I. continued

President of the Catenian Association of England, an Association of Catholic business and professional men of which I am still an overseas member.

I served for a period in the late war in the Army and after my discharge took an appointment in the Local Government Service and was attached to the permanent staff (clerical) of the Borough Engineer and Surveyor's Office in the Borough of Worthing, Sussex. I resigned this position to emigrate to Canada in February 1949.

I am married and have an excellent Catholic wife and a small daughter aged seven. Another dear member of my family is an aunt who emigrated with us.

At present I am employed in a permanent post with a Co-operative in the farming industry and have charge of accounts, being office manager and assistant manager.

The work of education strongly appeals to me and in this sphere I feel I could serve my new country in the very best way possible. The subjects I could teach best would be English, lower mathematics, accounts, Pitman's Shorthand. I have a good knowledge of Latin Grammar and would welcome in a very special way any opportunity to spread the word of God.

Trusting that you will consider my application favourably.

I remain, Very Reverend Father,

Yours obediently,

Bernard Callaghan.

Dear Madam:

The Personnel officer of our Department has shown me your Civil Service application form and I am therefore writing to you concerning a teaching position in one of our Indian schools. We require the services of Catholic teachers for day schools near Red Deer, Alberta, and near St. Paul, Alberta. If you have a First Class Teaching Certificate and five years of provincial experience the starting salary is $226.00 a teaching month for a ten month year.

I would be pleased to hear from you if you are interested in one of these teaching positions. If you are instead interested in a position as a dietitian, please let me know so that your application can be passed to the Department of National Health and Welfare.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.
July 10, 1950.

Mrs. Ethel M. McDougall,
P.O. Box 1438,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

My dear Mrs. McDougall:

Your letter of July 6 was delivered this morning and I must confirm the fact that there are very few schools available now as we made a drive before the end of the term so that we would have a staff guaranteed for the next academic year.

There is still, however, a vacancy at Chassawawin (Cedar Lake) south-east of The Pas and about 40 minutes by air.

A new school is projected near Kamsack, Saskatchewan, but the site of it has not yet been finalized. The Regional Supervisor at Regina, Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, might know of vacancies that arise through teachers changing their minds.

I had hoped that additional facilities would ready at Portage la Prairie so that the load on our teachers would be lighter.

Yours most sincerely,

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.
Portage la Prairie, Man.,
July 6th 1950

Educational Survey, Indian Affairs,
Dept of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Clark,

Have you any Day Schools available in Manitoba or Sask., which are not too inaccessible? I have been teaching here for three years and think I am due for a change. I applied last year but Mr. Best was so late in giving me an appointment that I accepted Mr. McLean's offer to stay on here. This spring he promised me a school at Grey Lake was mentioned, but he has filled that opening with a married couple. Now he has nothing to offer. Would you let me know what is available? I will be here till the end of July.

Sincerely yours,

Edith M. McCaughan
La Corey, Alta

Dear Sir,

A few months before the end of June term, I was asked to think for the year comming in Tunneyville School (Indian Reserve). It will be up to you to judge about it and your decision will be mine.

I have over 25 years of teaching experience in Quebec and two in Alberta schools. As far as 1948 I was in Community. I taught two years in normal school and in few other schools from grade 1 to 11.
asked to teach grade 12. I was transferred to another school where I have been principal for two years. This has stopped me in my studies. I was aiming to M.A.

I attended the University of Quebec and Montreal for this purpose. Now I am teaching in Alberta upon a letter of authority and a certificate which number is 38424. This allows me to teach from grade 1 to 8 in English.

Gurneyville School is far away. It will be more expensive for me to teach there. This is the reason why I kindly ask you for the salary of $200.00 a year.

Expecting to have an affirmative answer I remain your very thankful

Wilfred Broussard
Teacher of Beaver School
La Crete, Alta

Dear Mr Neary,

In as far as I can see Mr Wilbrod Borsseau has got the qualification of a very good school teacher in view of his own schooling and ability with the children. With the enclosed he has written himself and you will judge by yourself.

I particularly want to stress the fact that he is a convinced catholic and such a man we need to make the catechism classes interesting and instructive. Besides him and his wife can direct the children as well as their parents in many ways.

Considering that he will be accepted and given a decent salary

I remain, dear Sir,

Yours very truly in C.J. and M.I.

Rev. Father,

Some time ago you advertised for English teachers for the Indian schools. I readily accept my application for one of these positions.

I am an English speaking Canadian, male, aged 43, have one son, fifteen years old. I have had fifteen years teaching experience in nearly all grades up to 12th both boys and girls. I have also had several years experience in office work, accounting, selling etc.

For the past two years I have been teaching English to high school and intermediate boys and girls (grades 5-11) in a French school.

I shall be very pleased if you consider my application favorably.

Yours truly,
Thomas Lafortune.
133 Lewis Ave., Westmount,
Montreal 6, P.Q.

Superintendent of Indian Education,

220 Queen Street,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I wish to apply for the position of teacher (English Catholic teacher) for Indian Day schools, preferably in B.C.

I am a Catholic, English speaking, qualified teacher, male. I have one son aged 7. I am 43 years old, have had fifteen years teaching experience and several years experience in office work, accounting, selling, etc.

For the past two years I have been teaching English to French pupils, boys and girls, from grades 5 to 11.

I shall be very pleased if you give my application favorable consideration.

Yours truly,

Thomas Lefontaine.
July 10, 1950

Superintendent of Indian Education
220 Queen Street,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Do you employ unqualified teachers in your Indian Day Schools? If so I would like to know why.

I have Commercial Training and Supervision, also nursing experience, and teaching experience in public schools and in two Western Canada Residential Church Schools during past year.

The idea of a teacherage appeals to me if not too far from a railway.

The Provincial Inspector passed my Grade VIII Ontario pupils this year and told me I am "doing fine."

I have no experience alone among Indians, but if the parents would see that they come regularly to school I think I might do better work among them than where they only could for half day periods.

I shall go back to a church school next fall unless I could make some more satisfactory arrangement for a day school with the Village.

Yours Truly,

Mrs. A. R. Schulz.

Very Reverend Father,

I am writing to you with regard to a notice in the Ensign of 10 June on the need for Teachers in Indian Schools. I have wondered if I could be considered for an appointment.

Since March, 1949, I have taught as a substitute teacher in schools of the Montreal Catholic School Commission. I am eligible to qualify as a permanent teacher with the Commission as I have not taken the Normal School course.
I was educated privately at Merchant Taylors' School, Hertfordshire, England and took Responsions at Oxford University in 1937. From 1939 to 1946 I served as an officer in the Gurkha Brigade of the Indian Army, becoming a Major on the General Staff in 1944. From 1947 to 1948 I served as an executive on the civil staff of the British Intelligence Division of the Control Commission, Germany. I came to Canada in March, 1949.

It is possible that I may get an appointment as history teacher at Loyola High School, Montreal, in September.

I am able to travel any reasonable distance for an interview.

Yours faithfully,

W.H. Somerville

Re: Teachers

We have had some response to the advertisement you recently placed in the Calgary Herald.

(1) I am attaching an application form received from Mr. R. A. Gulliver, Okotoks, Alberta. Mr. Gulliver is single and is primarily interested in going north of the 56th base line where he would qualify for the Northern Allowance. In fact I know of no school where he could be assigned south of the 56th base line where he would receive a salary commensurate with his qualifications. Whitefish Lake, where another Anglican teacher is required, would have been ideal except that there is already a single female teacher there, leaving the problem of accommodation, and also the area is just south of the 56th base line. I should say that Mr. Gulliver made a very good first impression. He is awaiting advice as to the salary which he would receive.

(2) I am attaching copy of a letter received from Miss Orna McTaggart of Glenboro, Manitoba, and a copy of my reply.

(3) While on the subject of teachers, Mr. O.E. Smith of Irvine, Alberta, was just in this office. He is President of the Southern Local of the Alberta Teachers Association and is Principal of a six-room school at Irvine. Last year you corresponded with him regarding the Brocket school and also advised him that you might later be in a position to offer him a principalship at the Hobbema Day School. Mr. Smith stated that there appeared to be two major obstacles standing in the way of our obtaining good and sufficient teachers for the Indian Service (s) as an example, if a first-class teacher with ten years' experience applies for a position, invariably
is placed in the Grade Three salary bracket for the sixth year, that is $2280.00. Mr. Smith states that it would be preferable if he could be placed in the bracket for the tenth year; (b) teachers with considerable experience in Alberta schools have naturally built up a sizeable credit in their teacher's retirement or superannuation fund. When such teachers enter the Indian Service they have only one alternative and that is to accept a cash settlement for their credit in the Fund. If some method could be found to have this credit transferred to the Dominion Civil Servants' Superannuation Fund thus giving the teachers credit for their years of service in Provincial schools, we would have less difficulty in obtaining first-class teachers.

Cher Monsieur,

Je vous remercie d'avoir répondu si promptement à ma demande. Je m'aperçois de vous répondre après avoir rempli le blanc d'application en duplicata. Je n'ai pas le temps de faire un professeur plus expérimenté car mon cas est quelque peu flou.

Depuis déjà avancé en âge, 30 ans, j'ai une sorte de haut étude de raisons de ma sortie est que j'avais besoin d'un changement d'ambiance. Maintenant mon intention est de travailler pour quelques tant en suivant quelque cours du soir. Après ma sortie du Grand Séminaire de Montréal en études diverses, j'ai commencé un cours de comptabilité bilingue. Il me reste une année et demi pour terminer ce cours. Je fréquente encore après la seconde année, je le terminerai à l'automne.

Le premier faculté année de l'Université de Montréal. Cette science théologique comprend la doctrine et la morale, l'histoire du monde, de la psychologie, de la sociologie et de la pédagogie.

Depuis six ans, je m'occupe de manière constante de faire des activités les colonies de vacances et le scoutisme. Je chante et je fais chanter les enfants. Je ferai beaucoup de choses pour une bonne partie des élèves bénéficiant de cette année de ma présidence.

Dear Miss Ripley,

I was very pleased to get your letter a few days ago but I am sorry to hear that you have lost your father. What a wonderful long life he must have had! Not many people live to his great age nowadays. Did he have good health most of the latter years?

You and your sister who is a nurse must have been a great comfort to your mother during his last illness. I hope that your mother is keeping well.

You ask about full time church work. Have you thought about Indian school work? There is a most urgent need for a person with your training and ability in an Indian school. We receive really heart-breaking letters from our workers in these schools, telling of the shortage of teachers and other workers and how they are trying to carry on doing two and even three people's work.

The most recent letter describing this situation was from Bessie Quirt at the school in Fort George, on James Bay. Another recent letter was from a graduate of two years from Wabasca in the Diocese of Athabasca. She was having to do her work as a supervisor and besides that had to teach school in the mornings although she was not a trained teacher. She said that she was so busy that it was almost impossible for her to keep one lesson ahead of the class. In the afternoons the principal had to take on the class.

This is not an isolated condition. It happens in so many of our schools. Could you not give a year or two to this work?
I expect that Lytton would be your nearest school but there three in Southern Alberta—at Cardston, Brocket and Gleichen. I have visited all three of these schools. You would be making a wonderful contribution to the work of the church if you would do something like this. It is hard work, I know, but no church work is easy.

There must be great changes in the college since you were a student. Have you been back to Toronto recently? There are thirty-two students and fifteen who have their degrees from universities. We have new dormitories and a new wing is now being built between the two. We shall have a fine place when this is finished.

I wish you all joy and happiness in whatever work you undertake.

Dear Sir,

I am writing to inform you that shortly after I received your letter of May 12th, I wrote Mr. Sutherland to ask him if he intended to return to Goulais Bay in September. I waited all summer for an answer.

Two weeks ago I learned that he did not return, and I regret it very much that he did not inform me of his decision.

Having known that he would not return I would have written to Miss McNulty to ask her if she would take that school now, for she wanted to be transferred to Goulais Bay while I was there.

The reason why I did not want to exchange schools with her then was because the late Father Jim Dwyer S.J. did not want me to leave Goulais Bay School.
I am not against returning to that school, as I esteem the people there very highly, and the children are very good. I needed a rest from the place as I had worked hard while there.

I had taught the children how to knit, sew and cook, besides all the social work I did that the letters I sent you testified. It was also through my untiring efforts that rural mail was granted to Conlao Mission.

I was only nineteen when I entered an Indian school and I threw myself heart and soul into the work. I still ardently desire to return.

I would appreciate very sincerely if you would keep my name on your list, and if you are willing to have any services I would be glad to fill any vacancy.

Contrary to all expectations, my sick sister is improving.

Numerous prayers were offered for her recovery by the mission, and all her friends here also esteem her very highly.

I take this opportunity to wish you a very Merry Christmas.

Very respectfully yours,

Susan A. [signature]

March 29, 1951.

Re: Catholic Teachers for British Columbia.

On the occasion of Mr. Neary's visit to British Columbia it was suggested that when a School Inspector was appointed for the Maritime Provinces he be requested to endeavour to locate Catholic Teachers for the Indian Day Schools in this province. As the Department is aware, it is very difficult to secure the services of Teachers with Catholic affiliations for the schools of this province. Any action which the Department is able to take towards filling this need will be greatly appreciated.

The following list and description will perhaps assist the Department in meeting this need. Only schools where it is now known vacancies will occur have been listed and it is anticipated that other vacancies will become known at a later date:

1. MORICETOWN: This will be a new 2-room school the construction of which, it is expected, will start shortly. The present Teacher, Miss Joan Adams, is a Protestant and has been employed only until the end of the present term. Two Teachers will therefore be required at this point. The school is located on the Northern branch of the C.N.R., about 20 miles West of the white community of Smithers. Smithers is a town with a population of approximately 1000. Moricetown is also served by telephone and the Prince George - Prince Rupert Highway.

2. OKANAGAN: A second room will be added to this school in September. The school will then consist of two separate buildings, each with living quarters. It is located some 16 miles from Vernon, to which it is connected by a good road. The present Teachers are both unqualified and should be replaced for the term commencing September 1951.
3. IRISH CREEK: This is a new one-room school with attached living quarters, located 10 miles from Vernon on the same Reserve as the Okanagan school. One Teacher will be required.

4. INKAMBEPE: A new one-room school is now under construction at this point which will replace the very unsatisfactory building now being used. The work of the present teacher is unsatisfactory and he should be replaced.

5. ROCHER DEBOULE: It is anticipated that it will be possible to abandon the use of the rented log building with the construction of a new one-room school with attached Teacherage. The materials for this building are already on hand in the Babine Agency. The present Teacher, Mr. George Thiessen, is an excellent Teacher who has given complete satisfaction to the Department. He is, however, a Protestant and if a satisfactory replacement can be secured he should be transferred to a Protestant school. I would not suggest this transfer if I were not confident that the new school will be built, otherwise it would be difficult to retain the services of a satisfactory Teacher in view of the disgraceful condition of the existing building. The Rocher Deboule school is located three miles from the white community of Hazelton to which it is connected by a good road.

6. NASKAINILITH: The Department will recall correspondence concerning the work of Sister Patricia and Mr. Davey's recommendation that she be transferred to some school outside this Province. It is anticipated that the Department will be acting upon this recommendation which will create a vacancy for one Teacher at this point. The Naskainilith School is located approximately six miles from Chase. The building was constructed in 1949.

It will be noted from the above that at least eight Catholic Teachers will be required in this province.

If the appointment of an Inspector for the Maritime Provinces has not been made, it is suggested that Msgr. Mackey at Shubenacadie be contacted, although this office would prefer to secure teachers through Departmental officials.

W.S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir,

I have been advised to communicate with you, regarding employment in the Indian Schools in Canada.

In the Memorandum from the Ontario Department of Education, no mention is made of the academic standards which your School might expect from candidates for posts, and I should be grateful for any information you could offer me in this direction. This letter is largely in the nature of an enquiry, since there is possibility that my husband may come to work in Canada.

My main reason for writing to you is my interest in the Indian people. For twenty years I have read about them, and I should welcome an opportunity to work among them. I realise that my interest has been confined to books only, but I have endeavoured to study their history and present day life as widely as has been possible. At the moment I am reading books supplied by the American Embassy Library, which cover a good deal of ground, but, of course, my knowledge of actual conditions is comparatively small. I think first of teaching as a possible line of work, but I am very uncertain about my academic qualifications being sufficient for work of this kind. At present I am teaching in a Modern Secondary School, where I specialise in Art; my qualifications, however, are only those of a teacher trained in an Emergency Training College after a year's study and two years' supervised work in school, after which I was awarded a teaching certificate giving me full status. Before I was married in the Women's Air Force, I worked for five years as a secretary, my position was considered too important suddenly, and I am afraid that, under these circumstances, I did not sit for a School Certificate Examination. I regret, therefore, that there is little beyond my sincere interest that I can offer you, but I should be pleased to hear whether there is a possibility of finding work in connection with Indian people, whether this were teaching or some other kind of work for which my experience might be adequate.

Yours faithfully,

Kathleen M. Guiney

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration, Ottawa.

With reference to your Army Signals and correspondence regarding appointment of teachers, documents were received yesterday and your classification for Mr. T.J. Outhwaite, of Shamrock, Saskatchewan. I informed him of the salary range and stated that I would communicate with him later as soon as I had a definite school to offer.

A letter was received from Mrs. Evelyn Primrose, of Baring, Saskatchewan, and application forms were sent to her with more details. When her application is received it will go forward to you for your opinion, but, from her letter I feel she is the type of Indian day school teacher that we are looking for. One fact in her favour is she has specialized in primary teaching.

On your instructions Mr. Silversides was notified by registered mail that his service would not be required after June 30th. I had written to the Reverend Gray stating that we had reliable information that he would not be returning to the Fishing Lake School, and if such was the case, would he kindly submit his resignation in order to leave the school open for appointment. I have today written to Mr. F.L. Taggart advising him of approval of his appointment, and I also informed him that while I did not have the Reverend Gray's resignation it was practically assured.

It appears to me that there are plenty of the better type of teachers who are toying with the idea of Indian day school work, but it is very difficult to make a firm offer to them at the present time. When Mr. Ostrander returns from his holidays we will know just where teachers are needed, and I am sure that one of Mr. Ostrander's first duties in the office will be to look into this matter, and from the amount of applications received I think there would be no difficulty in finding teachers.

It is hard to know when the new schools will be completed, and I do not consider it good business to get any of the teachers too interested.
in these appointments as they might not be ready to open as soon as we anticipate.

If you have any further instructions that you wish me to carry out before Mr. Ostrander's return, please advise.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

À Monsieur le Directeur,

Comme suite à l'annonce faite dans la "Patrie" du 29 juin 1857, relatives à deux postes d'instituteurs, je me permets de vous exprimer ma situation.

Personnellement, je suis Français, âgé de vingt ans, et suis arrivé de France il y a deux mois. Je suis titulaire de mes deux baccalauréats en Mathématiques et ancien élève de la Faculté des Sciences de Marseille, que j'ai quittée pour venir au Canada. Bien que je ne sois titulaire d'aucun diplôme d'instituteur, il me semble que mon instruction peut suffire à un enseignement primaire, pour instruire les élèves en séparant le certificat d'études.

Ma femme, française comme moi, est venue en France et enseigne depuis deux ans à des élèves préparant le certificat d'études. Comme
Moi, elle ne fonde pas de diplôme d'institutrice mais de ses baccalauréats philosophiques.

Je me ferme de tous-dire qu'en France, un bachelier peut, en demandant officiellement, être immédiatement au bout de trois ans, si les résultats de sa profession, régulièrement connus par des inspecteurs, donnent satisfaction, il obtient le diplôme d'institutrice. C'est pourquoi, pensant que cela se fait peut-être au Canada, je me suis fermée de tous-fiers, ma requête.

Nous sommes tous deux catholiques, sans enfant, sans point de naissance, je suis formée à l'état de mes études antérieures et me ferme de vous assurer que j'ai été déterminée dans dernier le Père d'hommes de la ville de Marseille. Quant à ma femme, ses deux ans d'enseignement ont déjà une expérience.

Au cas où ma requête nous intéresserait, je vous serais très reconnaissante de me faire savoir assez rapidement, de façon à ce que je puisse me déterminer pour la prochaine année de ma femme, ainsi que tous enseignements suffisants si ce fut effectif.

Dans cette attente, je vous fie de croire, honnête et sincèrement, à l'expression de mes sentiments sincères. [Signature]

Monsieur le Secrétaire,

Ayant pris connaissance que vous avez besoin de professeurs pour votre école de Manouba, je me permets de vous offrir mes services.

Je suis un célibataire parce que j'étais congédié et du respect de mes parents, je fus presque obligé de demeurer dans cet état. Maintenant je suis entièrement libre et rien ne me ferait plus plaisir que d'exercer l'apostolat en dehors des grandes villes.

Je peux vous fournir deux diplômes français et anglais et comme expérience plusieurs années avec la note 90%, ces notes sont écrites sur mon certificat de recommandation et d'application envers les élèves.

Voici le rapport de ma lettre de recommandation que je peux vous fournir si vous le jugerez nécessaire avec le sceau imprimé :

À qui de droit :

La présente certifie que M. René Gilbert a été avec nous, Professeur émérite, il a une moyenne de 90% à son actif.

Je n'hésite donc pas à recommander M. René Gilbert à tous ceux à qui les présentes seront utiles ou nécessaires.

Je m'excuse de vous donner tous ces détails, mais ils sont nécessaires pour vous. Actuellement je pourrais prendre un engagement dans
un collège comme professeur, mais je préfère la campagne.

Ma santé est excellente et je pense vous fournir mon dernier examen médical en détail.

Je peux aussi chanter les messes et autres Règles à la bonne école, malgré de cérémonies, avec votre permission je peux que lui rendre ce service car je connais parfaitement la liturgie.

Si dans une de vos écoles il y a plusieurs divisions, cela ne me ferait pas de différence; les heures de classe ainsi que la bonne formation des enfants ne me serait pas une surcharge.

Je peux vous dire aussi que mes résultats en classe ont toujours été très appréciés.

Permettez-moi de vous demander si la classe se fait seulement en français ou je peux enseigner en anglais, mais je veux le dire sincèrement, je toujours fait la classe en français, plus une heure et demie d'anglais par jour.

Il me serait plaisir de recevoir de vous une lettre d'ici quelques jours et je peux vous assurer de mon entier dévouement. Si cela vous va monsieur le directeur, je serais prêt à signer l'engagement si vous avez besoin d'aide, je serais prêt à vous les fournir.

Comme je vous le disais, étant donné dans ce moment et si la chose est possible, je pourrais prendre une pension ou bien une bourse désignée par vous-même et même faire la maîtrise proposée; c'est à vous de me juger et je bois à votre service.

Je demande actuellement chez mon père, pas loin de mes frères, qui est suffisamment pour couvrir les frais. En attendant de vous les détails si la chose est possible de votre côté et je serais très content si vous voulez prendre une situation que j'y vois ou ailleurs.

Je demeure René Gilbert

Dear Sir,

We have recently discovered an Indian girl in Truro, Miss Helen Christmas, who has far more than average ability. She is a mature girl in her late 20's. Because she was an invalid in hospital from the age of 3 to 16, she missed schooling, but has since that time gone as far as Grade 9. She hasn't the Mathematics and Science necessary for a Nova Scotia license; but she has the personality, grace, and self composure that would make her an excellent pattern for young Indians to follow.

My recommendation is that she be appointed a Travelling Teacher to the Indian schools of Nova Scotia, teaching singing, speech habits, behavior, and dozens of things needed in society but not taught in ordinary schools. At least, they are not taught by example.

Are you willing to ask your Nova Scotia representative to meet Miss Christmas and to consider what use he can make of her? She belongs to the Sydney Reserve. Her father was Chief at the time of her birth. At present she is head chamber maid at the Stanley Hotel, Truro. Several Truro citizens are now helping her with her education -- especially in speech. Last week, she addressed the Kiwanis Club, which was broadcast. She is giving a series of 13 broadcasts over CKCL, the local Truro Station.

It would be foolish to delay her usefulness by asking her to prepare herself for a regular teacher's license -- which requires subjects that not one Indian in 100 will want or need. A special license to teach what all need seems logical. I assure you, she is worth special consideration.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Re: Schooling Facilities,
Marie River Group of Indians,
Slave Band 2, Fort Simpson, N.W.T.

Fort Norman, N.W.T.,
Sept. 8, 1951.

I refer to your Army message dated Sept. 5, wherein it is stated that Therese Carterette, anthropologist from the United States wishes an appointment as teacher for Marie River group of Indians.

At the time your wire was received at this office, I was absent, visiting the Marie River group of Indians, investigating the possibilities of a school at this point.

The Marie River group of Indians belong to Slave Band 2 of Fort Simpson, N.W.T., and reside 45 miles up the Mackenzie River from Fort Simpson, at a point known as Marie River. There are approximately twelve families in this group, who have resided at this point for many years. They have always operated on a co-operative basis and at the present time are requesting schooling facilities for the fifteen children of their group.

With regard to a request for a school of this group of Indians, I wish to advise that in the 1951-52 estimates an allotment was requested for the purpose of erecting a school at this point, and a further recommendation in this regard was forwarded by our Regional Supervisor, Mr. G.H. Gooderham, to the Superintendent of Education, in letter File: 142/16-3 dated September 18, 1950. We are also in receipt of copy of correspondence addressed to the Northern Administration, Dept. of Resources and Development, File 4235-9-3 dated December 22, 1950, wherein it is stated that this matter should be discussed at a meeting of the sub-committee on education of the Northwest Territories Council. To date we have had no further word on this matter.
At the present time we have an excellent opportunity of obtaining the services of Miss Teresa Carterette, a student of anthropology at the University of Chicago. Miss Carterette came to this country for the purpose of studying our local Indians. She has studied social education and is presently writing a thesis for her master's degree in anthropology. She is a United States citizen and it would appear that she is well fitted for the teaching duties that would be required at this point.

The Indians of Marie River group are making all arrangements for this year at least, to supply housing facilities and schoolroom space for the starting of the school for their children. As can be seen, we would receive at least one year's schooling for the children of this group with very little cost to the Department other than the salary of Miss Carterette. As she is a citizen of the United States it is best that that salary therefore would have to be paid on a monthly basis. As she would be assuming all welfare duties of this group, I would suggest that a salary of $200.00 per month, without Northern Allowance, be allowed.

As stated previously, there are fifteen children in this group of school age and we have been assured that the daily attendance for the school year would be at least twelve. The Marie River group of Indians are industrious and are attempting to be very self reliant. We cannot stress too strongly our recommendation in starting a school at this point by obtaining the services of Miss Carterette as schoolteacher.

We realize that due to the lateness of the season it is impossible to obtain the necessary textbooks etc., for the starting of this school, from Ottawa, however if the Department concur in the hiring of Miss Carterette as teacher, we will attempt to obtain textbooks and other necessary supplies from the surplus on hand at our other Indian Day Schools throughout the Agency.

As the Marie River group of Indians are predominantly of the Catholic Religion the Indian Act requires that the teacher be also of this faith, and as Miss Carterette is of the Catholic Religion, we consider that this point would be covered.

In Fort Simpson there is a Roman Catholic Indian Day School, but it will be realized that the transportation of this country would not allow these children from the Marie River Group to attend this school. It is noted in your Army message that a letter is to follow from your office in this regard. Should you request information that we have not already supplied, we will supply it at the first opportunity. Should the Dept. immediately concur with our suggestion that Miss Carterette be appointed teacher, may we be informed by Army message.

Yours truly,

L. Carter, Superintendent,
Fort Norman Indian Agency.
Fort Norman, N.W.T.,

Dear Mr. Neary:

In our correspondence of July of last year, concerning Mr. Clarence J. Bernard's and my application for positions in the Indian schools, you were extremely kind; and to support your confidence, I should like to tell you of a new development since that time—one of which you, in charge of educational work, might at least wish to know.

Harrison Shorthand (first Copyrighted in the Dominion) is becoming academically known throughout all Canada. It is the subject, as you have probably already noticed, of a series of 15 articles currently appearing in the Canadian High News (which has the largest circulation of any high-school paper in the language). There were 2,100 new subscribers (more than 6,000 new readers) last week in Winnipeg alone.

The present articles have to do with "Shorthand for Personal Note-taking"; but you will be interested to know these are presently to appear in the form of a manual, too. You may wish to know, also, that the use of the system is not confined to personal note-taking; rather, it is also available for complete secretarial and reporting training.

The inclosed bulletin will give the background, nature, and claims of Harrison Shorthand; and if you would like further information on the system, at any time, it would always be a pleasure to send it to you.

I have another reason for writing to you, Mr. Neary: Should suitable opportunity arise, I hope to be in Canada. I am a Canadian; but my associate in this work, Mr. Bernard, is not Canadian. He wishes to become one, on taking up residence in Canada; but should there be any difficulty, at any time, our case would be facilitated by the fact that someone in the Department of Citizenship and Immigration has, thus early in the matter, been at least familiar with his name. I shall therefore be grateful for your keeping this correspondence in your files. Thank you.

Very truly yours,

To Educators:

The following is a copy of a letter just sent to a prominent Educator:

Dear Mr. -- :

In answer to your request for further information concerning Harrison Shorthand, it is a pleasure to submit these data for your consideration:

Background of Harrison Shorthand

Twenty years were spent in the conscientious teaching of the principal systems of shorthand on all levels (including that in which you are most interested). This included one entire year, in teachers' college, in specific research into the relative merits of five of the prevailing systems. Three of these were taught in regular class work, side by side but in separate classes; two were taught in research groups organized for that special purpose. All relevant conditions were rigidly controlled as far as circumstances would then (and probably ever would) permit.

The results of this research (the report on which brought outstanding commendation from the Government) were all, when favorable, incorporated into the construction of Harrison Shorthand; an equally serious effort was made to avoid all weaknesses that had been shown.

Nature of Harrison Shorthand

Only three points need be considered in the objective evaluation of any shorthand system; that is, its ease of learning, its essential speed, and its essential legibility.

"Ease of learning" must not be at the expense of sacrificing the acquisition of an adequate and thoroughly-mastered vocabulary. The ease of learning of Harrison Shorthand is not achieved in this way; rather, it rests upon (1) the comparative simplicity of its theory, (2) the ready availability of longhand transcripts (side by side with all shorthand material), and (3) the fact that the text is not merely the presentation of a system, but that it is also a course of study, with specific directions to the student and teacher as to what is to be done (and not to be done) every step of the way. It is sufficiently easy to learn, in fact, that several of our best students were formerly subnormal in a prevailing system.

"Essential speed" does not lie in the ultimate unlearning of thousands of elementary forms and the learning of countless thousands of others of essentially arbitrary nature. The speed of Harrison Shorthand is inherent in the nature of the system itself and rests upon (1) the comparative brevity of its forms from the very beginning, and (2) the dominance of straight lines and mere ticks.

"Essential legibility" does not rest upon undue emphasis of either context or the writer's memory of the material he has recorded. The legibility of Harrison Shorthand is, again, inherent in the system itself and rests upon:
1. The contrasting length of its strokes
   A size-ratio of 1-to-2 (rather than the prevailing ratio of only 1-to-2); thus allowing for some measure of distortion, in high-speed writing, without necessary loss of legibility at this point.

2. The origin of its strokes
   These are not based upon the "scrawling fluency" of longhand, with its comparative illegibility; rather, upon the definiteness of the straight line, circle, and angle (always accompanied by the speed which comes from its brevity and dominance of straight lines).

3. The contrasting slant of its strokes
   The contrast of four (not merely two) distinctive slants.

4. The sharpness and angularity of its forms
   Not based upon the comparative uncertainty of curvilinear forms; rather, upon the sharpness of straight lines, ticks, and angles.

Claims of Harrison Shorthand

1. It is claimed that, assuming equal teacher-ability and student-aptitude and equal periods of time for class and preparation, Harrison Shorthand will produce "at least the usual results in one-half the usual time"--and all experience thus far has substantiated the accuracy of that claim;

2. High-school students of average aptitude, studying under teachers of average ability, should have no difficulty in passing five-minute tests on standard material (1.4 syllable intensity) at 100 words a minute at the end of the first year;

3. Business-school students, under similar conditions of aptitude, reach 100 words a minute, on the same material, in approximately three months;

4. Some students will do better still, as will be evident from the following results, secured in six weeks and entirely with beginners, in the First Summer School for Teachers of Harrison Shorthand which closed recently in this city:

   a. All completed the theory in three weeks;
   b. All except three passed, at the end of six weeks, five-minute tests at 80 words a minute or higher (the three exceptions were writing 75 words a minute on the same material);
   c. Three passed (two of them without an error), at the end of six weeks, the Regents examination for the completion of second-year shorthand.

Dear Sir,

My interest in reaching out for a position in your Boarding School stems in large measure from conversations with a graduate nurse who is a member of our Church. This lady, trained here, served two years in one of the Boarding schools out west. Life in the Institution was no bed of roses. But she loved the Indian children and she declare they were the best patients she ever nursed. Not one pupil of the school reached High School Entrance while she was there. She attributes the poor showing to the fact that "permit teachers were engaged, who knew little about how to present the subject matter or to make the lessons..."
interesting. Teaching appointments there are made, she said, by the Principal, a fine man.

The lady still gets letters from former pupils of the schools, and when she mentioned recently that one of the teachers would be leaving at the end of June, I applied. As a matter of fact, a sister mine lives about sixty miles from the school. And since my husband's death last winter, life here has been lonely. I have no dependents and I like underprivileged children. Besides while teaching county school in Ontario, I always kept pupil up for Entrance. We never had a failure; so I feel that I could enlist the Indian children's cooperation too and bring them right along.

Well, the Principal wants to hire me, but he states: "Our teachers are on terms; we pay $150 a year and maintenance (I presume for ten months of each year)."
I am familiar with the Indian Affairs' salary schedule for teachers holding Permanent First Class certificates. And while I am not "commercially minded," I still subscribe to the theory that a workman is worthy of his hire. If I contribute my services to the work of educating Indians, I shall work hard; I should hope to receive the same treatment as certain other Civil Service teachers with precisely the same qualifications doing precisely the same work in certain other Indian schools in Canada.

So, I explained in my reply that, in view of the very modest stipend offered, I preferred to let the matter simmer for a few days. And I promptly wrote to you to determine whether duly qualified teachers in Prairie Boarding Schools for Indian children would finally be expected to serve for about nine
hundred dollars and board for

ary is supplemented by grants

Dear Mrs. Inglehart:

We regret that we cannot advise you what classification and salary you would be entitled to receive on our 1951 salary schedule until we have received the completed application form which was sent to you on June 21, 1952. As previously stated the completion of this form obligates you in no way.

The Education Division of the Indian Affairs Branch pays the salary of teachers employed in all Indian Day Schools and in a few Residential Schools. In all other Residential Schools the salaries of the teachers are paid by the Administration of the Residential School.

Retirement of teachers is voluntary at 60 and compulsory at age 65. Before retirement to pension a teacher must have qualified for permanent employment in an Indian School in compliance with the requirements of the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

Philip Phelan

Since we have now reached mid-June and contracts for the schools at Fond du Lac and Stony Rapids only have been awarded, it would seem reasonable to assume that whatever other building may be started in the current fiscal year, it cannot be ready for September 1st, 1952. I am, therefore, assuming that these two are the only new schools for which I shall be required to find teachers. Would you please confirm this?

I would suggest that teachers for these two schools be appointed now or when they can be procured and that they be dispatched to the schools on September 1st whether they are completely finished or not. Local arrangements with the missionaries could be made to commence the school work in temporary quarters at the missions until such time as the school buildings are ready. In making this suggestion, I have in mind the teacher shortage. After July 15th there isn't a really suitable teacher to be had. My teacher appointment problem is further aggravated by my absence from my desk at Calgary during the month of July. While I shall be doing my office work in Victoria as usual, there will be some delay in answering letters and I shall not be able to interview prospective teachers personally. Because of this situation I am endeavouring to have all of my teacher vacancies filled by June 27.

It is suggested that any other new schools still under construction in September 1952 remain unused until the following September. This will avoid any hasty finishing work and will enable me to get good teachers for them.

Dear Sir:

I have come out west for three summers to teach teachers about child art. My permanent position has been with the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts, where I am in charge of Children's Education in Art.

Last year and this one also, I have been a volunteer teacher of Indians and Esquimos at the Camsell Hospital. I must say it has been one of the most interesting and rewarding jobs I have ever had. The Matron, Miss Taylor, nurses and nurses have all been most co-operating toward my efforts. My method of work is to give these natives the opportunity of expressing their own talents, but I make very few suggestions, but I do study the materials I give them as suitable for a child who is in bed and who has had practically no previous art training. As a result I have a valuable collection of work from young and old - drawings, paintings, plastering models - card-board ships, wire horses; and plenty of variety of work from Esquimos also. I leave the University on August 18 and am going to the coast.

Miss Tench a teacher of Indians near here suggested I write you and ask if the Indian Department would take me on a coastal ship to Indian Missions in B.C.

I also hope to work for a week at the hospital in Naimo, B.C., in order to compare the work of the Plains Indian with that of the North West Coast Indians.

May I say again Camsell Hospital has a wealth of talent there. They are in the habit of copying magazine art, which I consider an insult to any native art. Anthropologists in the East in Toronto and Montreal were astonished that there exists so much talent in drawing and painting as I had collected to show them.

Yours sincerely,

(Miss) Audrey A. Taylor

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am having extreme difficulty in getting teachers for our schools here in Ontario.

The Bulletin Board in Normal Schools is literally plastered with offers of positions from various school boards with salaries ranging from $2000 to $2600.

Our salary schedule is quite in line with the province when experience is considered. Where we are losing ground is on the initial salaries. I find it almost impossible to get anyone with a 2nd starting at less than $1800 to $2000 and people with a 1st just simply will not go out under $2000 to $2600. Most of those are folk who have had only two or three year's teaching.

I suppose we could get some teachers from the Maritimes or Manitoba but we did have some criticism from Ontario M.P.'s concerning this and a suggestion that we should stick to Ontario teachers. How much attention we should pay to this, is for you to decide but I think you should be cognizant of the salary situation which obtains here at present.

Dear Mr. Philan:

Re: Telegram July 18 - Welfare Teacher, Fort Good Hope

After my interview with Mr. Jacobson June 4th, I did not expect to hear about schools in the N.W.T., at least not this year. Your telegram was a surprise and indeed a pleasure. I wish to thank you for the favorable consideration you gave my application and for considering me for the position of Welfare Teacher.

I signed my contract with the Brooke S.O. Rivels Camp, N.W.T., June 7 because I thought my application for your schools had come to naught. Now as I stated in my telegram I would accept the position if I could obtain release.
For two days I have been trying to locate Captain R.O. Jones, the Official Trustee, in whom rests the decision. All we could find out—Capt. Jones is on holidays until Aug. 2, at Kenora, possibly Keewatin Beach. Wing Commander Davis, commander of the camp, would like to help me but does not like to interfere in Capt. Jones' field, and also fears they might be opening school in September (short a teacher if I am released).

Everything seems to be against me. To wait much longer, or until Aug. 2 will be too late for you to fill your schools. If there was any way you could help me and at the same time not leave Rivers stranded I would appreciate it, but right now it looks as if I will be unable to accept your offer.

As I told Mr. Jacobsen I would re-apply early next year. After my interview with him I had decided
To make teaching in the territories my work for the next phase of my life, I would greatly appreciate it if the Department would hold my application and records until next year, and I can assure you I shall be in a position to accept what you offer.

Once again thank you.

Sincerely,

Dear Canon Cooks,

With reference to our telephone conversation this morning, I am forwarding herewith copies of our salary schedule. You will note that teachers are placed in one of four classifications, Grade I, Grade II, Grade III and Grade IV. Teachers with no certification are rated as Grade II teachers with Second Class Certificates are rated as Grade II teachers with First Class Certificates are rated as Grade III, and specialists such as primary teachers, who are specially qualified and devote at least half of the teaching time to the work in which they have had special training, are classified as Grade IV.

In general, the classification of Welfare Teacher is restricted to those schools which are located in the far north and where service is expected for twelve months of the year. We have very few of this classification, and I feel that it would be well if those to whom you are sending this information were warned that the classification is given only under very special circumstances, and after a very careful review by the department of all circumstances.

A maximum of five years of credit may be given for previous experience in placing teachers on the salary scale, except where the teacher is simply being transferred from one Indian school to another. However, if there is any break in service and the teacher has more than five years' experience, the teacher starts as having five years of experience only, and is placed on the salary schedule at the sixth period.

.....
As you are aware, teachers employed in day schools operating for the full academic year of ten months, may be classified for superannuation purposes as Civil Servants, providing they meet the qualifications, one of which is two years of satisfactory service with this department. Such a classification carries with it all the benefits of the Federal Civil Service Superannuation scheme. Immediately on appointment, however, teachers contribute to the pension fund in accordance with the provisions of the Act which apply to Civil Servants. If they make application and are accepted as Civil Servants for the purposes of superannuation, their pension contributions are transferred to their credit under this scheme. If they leave the service before they are pensionable, all their contributions are returned to them.

I think it would be well if you would tell the Bishops that the department welcomes the nomination of qualified teachers from the Churches, but the actual appointment is made by the department. However, the department usually accepts the nomination, providing the teacher is qualified and there are no other grounds for anticipating that the appointment would not be satisfactory. The department, of course, has full control of all teachers employed in our day schools and may dismiss a teacher without reference to the nominating authority.

The policy outlined in the preceding paragraph has been in general practice for a number of years, and I merely mention it so that there shall be no misunderstanding.

As you know, there is at present a very acute shortage of teachers throughout Canada. A recent editorial in the "Ottawa Citizen" gave the number as 10,000. This is somewhat in excess of what is usually quoted, but there is no doubt that the shortage runs in the thousands. Because of this, the department must be in a position to engage teachers without delay and is not obligated to wait for the nomination of the Bishop if a suitable applicant is available. I am asking the Regional Supervisors to inform the Bishops of vacancies as soon as possible, and it would be helpful if the Bishops could submit the names of applicants immediately they are known without waiting for vacancies to occur. The department begins advertising in April for teachers for the term commencing September.
I wish to thank you for your very kind offer to solicit the support of the Bishops of the Anglican Church in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

R. F. Davey,
Asst. Superintendent of Education

May 26, 1948.

Colonel Bernard Neary,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I am writing you re a position for next term. I am feeling quite well again, and able to return to work.

Would you kindly advise me where the vacancies are for next term. I would consider a one-roomed school as well as any other should there be a vacancy. I don't suppose Scantlebury, Manitoba day school would be vacant.

I intend being in Ottawa
before long, but thought I had better write rather than wait as there would probably be resignations end of story.

Yours truly,

J. G. Hainsworth
June 1, 1948.

Dear Mrs. Ross:

I was glad to receive your letter of the 26th ultimo and am pleased to know that you are still very active.

Attached is one of our regular application forms which I would appreciate if you would complete and return to us. We will have vacancies in several schools during the coming academic year and if you decide to leave the residential school, there is no doubt that we can place you.

Owing to lack of funds, we have been unable to rebuild the St. Clair School, although we are making plans that we hope will result in school accommodation being available late this fall.

With kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Mrs. M.B. Ross,
Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary

OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Norbert Bellavance, qualified teacher from the Winnipeg Normal School, has taught thirteen years in schools attended by our catholic Indians and Half-Breeds.

He has shown a preference for schools located on remote and isolated Indian Reservations, in order to of service to those Indian children most in need of education and religious instruction.

Mr. Bellavance has always discharged his duties conscientiously and generously, and he has proved to be skilful and methodical in his teaching.

He is as well a wise adviser to the Indians who seek his aid to the solution of their various personal and community problems.

I recommend him strongly, dear Mr. Neary, because he is one of the few qualified teachers who has the necessary courage and self-denial required to endure long months of isolation among our Indians.

Please accept, dear Sir, the expression of my deep respect,

[Signature]

Re: Advertising accounts -
Your File 0-11-2

With reference to your letter of the 8th instant, Cheque No. 15915 was forwarded to the Vancouver Sun on October 28th, in payment of their account dated July 22nd.

We agree with you that there is frequently considerable delay in paying advertising accounts, and in future we will watch them and make every possible endeavour to have them passed for payment sooner than they have been. However, we have our troubles also, as in some cases the newspapers simply forward an account and do not give us sufficient information to file them even, and this causes delay. When we find the file, we have to submit the account to the King's Printer for taxation before the Treasury Branch will pay it. This also causes delay.

However, as mentioned above, we will endeavour to have the advertising accounts receive more prompt attention.

GENERAL MATERIALS

Our list of present vacancies in Saskatchewan includes Shoal Lake and Sturgeon Lake. It is noted that you have listed Shoal Lake but omitted Sturgeon Lake. Is there a reason for this omission?

You will, no doubt, have received a copy of official salary letter sent to Mr. F.J. Daniels dated October 2, 1951 advising him that he had been appointed as substitute teacher during the absence of Mr. Lowe. It is presumed that Mr. Lowe will be able to return to the Red Earth Indian Day School on January 1, 1952. Would you please submit a report on Mr. Lowe's condition sometime during the month of December indicating his probable date of return to duty.

Re: Congo Bridge Indian Day School -
St. Mary's School, Fredericton.

Apparently we will require a number of teachers due to some tardy resignations. I have heard through rumor lately that Miss Gilberta Alain of Burnt Church is getting married. I definitely understood when I visited that school that both teachers were remaining. I am writing to Superintendent Blakes for confirmation of this rumor. Possibly, Ottawa has received her resignation. Besides her, there is a vacancy at Maniwaki and possibly two at Fredericton and we have not yet received the acceptance of the vacant position at Park Savard Hospital. Miss Bertha Bruyere, who taught in Ontario, sent her application for this position. However, for obvious reasons, I do not think that her services would be suitable. I had two other teachers in mind and I have written to them but to date I have received no reply. I think it would be wise to advertise to obtain teachers to fill these positions.

Advertisements should be inserted in the following: Le Droit, Ottawa - La Presse, Montreal - Telegraph Journal, Saint John, N.B.- L'Action Catholique, Quebec - and the Insign, Montreal.

REGULATIONS

1. The schedule is based upon the minimum qualification of an Interim First Class "B" Certificate and does not apply to teachers holding Second Class, Conditional or Special Certificates, or to Specialists. These teachers will be dealt with individually by the Board and assigned to such positions on the scale as their qualifications merit.

2. Annual increments shall be effective on each anniversary date of the teacher's entry into the school system until the maximum is reached.

3. Special qualifications

(a) Any teacher or principal completing two summer school sessions with a total credit of 4½ units of professional work over and above the requirements for a Permanent First Class Certificate shall receive $50 above his or her basic salary.

(b) Any teacher or principal having a total credit of 9 units of professional work over and above the requirements for a Permanent First Class Certificate shall receive $100 above his or her basic salary.

(c) Any teacher or principal taking academic or professional work above a minimum standing of Grade XII or First Year University shall receive credits above their basic salary as follows:

(1) One year's training - Nil
   e.g. Normal School

(2) Two years' training - $100
   e.g. Normal School and 2nd Year Univ.

(3) Three Years' training - $200

(4) Four years' training - e.g. B.A. $400

(5) Five years' training - $500

(6) Six years' training - at least two of $600 which must be in education, e.g. Normal or Faculty plus one other year in education.
(7) First Class Grade "A" Certificate $50

Note: There shall be no duplication of values in Clause 3 (c)

(d) The onus of making claim under the special qualifications clause rests with the teacher. A salary increase resulting from such a claim shall date from the first of the month following recognition of the validity of the claim.

(e) The committee for the evaluation of Special Qualifications shall consist of the Chairman of the Board Management Committee, the Chairman of the Salary Committee of the Flin Flon Local of the M.T.S., and the School Superintendent.

4. The Cost of Living Bonus shall be computed on a basic index of 176.3 and it is understood that all previous Cost of Living Bonus up to that point has now been incorporated in the Salary Schedule. An annual adjustment of $1.50 per month per point change in the Cost of Living Index as published on December 1st. shall be made, this to be effective the following January 1st.

5. These regulations and salary schedule shall be effective as from September 1, 1952, and shall remain in full force and effect until amended or cancelled by the Board in negotiation with representatives of the Flin Flon Local of the Manitoba Teachers' Society but shall not abrogate or vary any teacher's agreement signed with the School Board.

Dear Mr. Marcoux:

It gives me pleasure to acknowledge your request of recent date for salary schedules for Flin Flon and The Pas as well as for any observations which I might wish to make regarding Indian education in general.

The requested schedules are herewith enclosed. That of Flin Flon is for the year 1952-53, and is likely to be increased in 1953-54. The schedule for The Pas is the revised schedule which will go into effect in 1953-54. The general trend in salaries will be upward again this year in Manitoba; greatly increased provincial grants have made this possible. Schools which do not follow the trend in offering increased salaries will find themselves under a great handicap in competing for the better teachers. The importance of securing competent staff for your Indian schools cannot be overemphasized.

In the North, where costs of travel are high, I have found it of help in securing teachers to offer as an added inducement free transportation, at least one way, to their schools. Nearly all of the outlying districts in my field, have at my suggestion, adopted the foregoing policy with good results. The more remote the
school the greater the importance of doing something to at least partially defray costs of travel.

In my view, an adequate library is only second in importance to competent staff. When a new school is built there should be a large initial expenditure for library of at least one hundred dollars. Thereafter, an expenditure of fifty dollars per room is suggested. The choice of books is extremely important for Indian children. It is also important that when ordered, the books should be available. I do not know whether you have a library staff taking care of the foregoing work or not, but the service which a competent library staff could give would be invaluable.

Most teachers make use of the library requisition privileges. A few make no use of them, and others not to the fullest extent. It occurs to me that if the January bulletin carried the suggestion that salary cheques for March would be payable only after the library requisition had been received that the problem would be resolved quite readily.

From our various discussions, I know that we are agreed upon the need for Practical Arts courses for the older pupils; also on the advisability of utilizing Visual Aids, radio programmes, and the gramophone wherever possible. I am glad to note that some headway has been made in regard to these things, and that greater progress lies ahead.

-over-
Occasionally I find a teacher of long experience and of considerable teaching ability teaching on a Grade I certificate. Where the work of such teachers has been successful over a considerable period, I would suggest that it might be in order to raise the classification for salary purposes. A case in point would be that of Mrs. Ann Graffin at Oxford House. If it is possible to do so without violating the regulations, I would be quite willing to suggest that Mrs. Graffin be given a Grade II Certificate.

In the course of my inspection work, I have noted that there is some very good singing done at many of the Indian Schools. It occurs to me that perhaps it might be possible to have such a group as the Boys' Choir at Cross Lake R.C. Residential School take part in the Musical Festival at The Pas next year. I know that they would acquit themselves well, and would be welcomed at The Pas.

In regard to Curriculum, the greatest problem in Indian schools is to achieve a satisfactory standard of oral and written expression. This will take a great deal of time and patience, but I feel that progress is being made.

I am particularly pleased to note the attempt being made to staff your schools with competent teachers. This, of course, is the most immediate way of raising standards in your schools. It is also worthy of note that there is a gradually increasing
number of students availing themselves of the opportunity to take advanced academic training. This is an encouraging feature. In the long run the success of this venture will be largely determined by the degree of success in placing students who have taken such training in suitable employment. As racial prejudice still exists, part of the problem lies in eliminating this barrier. Every student of an Indian school who goes out from school, and makes a success of something worthwhile is helping to make it that much easier for the next who follows.

It has been a pleasure to inspect the Indian schools in this Division during the past six years, and to note the progress which is being made. I should like to congratulate you on it.

I trust that the foregoing observation may be of some assistance to you.

All best personal regards.

Yours sincerely,

H. P. Moffat,
School Inspector

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH

628 Public Building,

April 11, 1953.

Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Re: Teachers - Employment

With reference to your letter of April 2nd, file 1-1-LX-2 (EF), we fully agree with your suggestion that advertisements for teachers should be inserted in the two chief Alberta papers at an early date. I have already sent out letters to teacher training institutions and have received a number of inquiries. The advertisement as worded in your letter is adequate, but change 620 to 628.

The only teacher that cannot be re-employed next year is Mr. Sealy of Saddle Lake School. He came to us from Ontario, hired by mail at the end of August when we were desperate for Catholic teachers. He is far too incompetent and immature. Both Mr. Racette's and my report indicate the inadvisability of retaining him.

L. G. P. Waller,
Inspector of Schools.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attn. Mr. P. Phelan, Superintendent of Education

We have your letter of April 4, 1953, file No. 1-1-LX-2 (E7) re teacher vacancies and advertisements.

We have already sent a circular letter to all teachers an exact copy of which is attached. The answers are coming in now and we hope to have them all in by May 1st.

It will be very difficult to secure the services of teachers this year due to the considerable increase in the Government school grants which in turn reflects on the salaries paid the teachers.

We are sending you a copy of a letter received from Inspector Moffat of The Pas which gives the salary schedules of the northern part of the Province, also a copy of a letter received from the Registrar of the Department of Education giving the salary schedule for permit teachers in this Province.

After perusing this material you will probably agree that we will have to do something about our initial salaries if we want to secure teachers for next year.

Regarding the advertisement, please note that our offices are now at 309 Hargrave Street instead of 537 Dominion Public Building. I think that the first of May will be the right time to have it in the newspaper.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

I am also enclosing a paper clipping showing the teacher salary trend.

MAJOR MACKAY

Reference your memorandum to the Minister's Private Secretary, dated April 28, regarding an advertisement to be published in order to secure experienced teachers from the British Isles for Indian Schools in Western Canada. I have two comments to make regarding the proposed advertisement. First I note that this would be published only in English papers. I feel that good teachers might be attracted from Scotland and Ireland, if we could draw this offer to their attention. I believe that the text of the suggested advertisement is rather lengthy. As you know, the cost of advertising in United Kingdom is very expensive, especially if you advertise in metropolitan papers.

In view of the foregoing may I suggest that you authorize Superintendent L.G. Cumming, London, to place certain advertisements in some selected papers in Scotland, Ireland and England, at his discretion and at the lowest possible cost.

I refer to my letter of April 10th, in which it was recommended that an advertisement for teachers be run in Eastern papers as well as in our Vancouver dailies. As it is impossible to staff our B.C. schools without drawing on applicants from the East, I would request that an advertisement for teachers for the Indian schools in this province be inserted in Eastern publications as quickly as possible.

July 29, 1953.

Of recent months we have received several representations that our salary schedule for teachers is not keeping pace with those in force in various provincial rural areas but we have not received any concrete evidence which would support this statement. If you feel that our salaries are not in line with those paid in rural provincial areas, I would appreciate having from you a submission indicating the salary schedule which you think should be in force. Your submission should, of course, be supported by sample provincial schedules.

It may be that the policy of providing free living accommodation will have to be changed. I would, therefore, appreciate your bearing this in mind and indicating in your submission an alternative schedule which should be effective if living accommodation is not provided free of charge.

If you believe our salary schedule is comparable or better than the schedule in effect in the rural provincial areas of your region, I shall appreciate your informing me of this.

I beg to report the receipt of the following communication, from Russell T. Perrier Esq., Superintendent of Indian Education, Ottawa, dated September 17th inst:-

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, September 17, 1923.

To Indian Agents and Teachers of Indian Day Schools.

"Salaries of day school teachers, in the future, as in the past, will be paid at the end of September, December, March and June on receipt of the quarterly School Returns. It has been decided, however, to pay these salaries on the basis of ten teaching months in the school year.

"For example, a teacher who is being paid salary at the rate of $500.00 a year will receive $60.00 at the end of September, and $180.00 at the end of each of the three other quarters, provided the school is open. Bonus will be paid, as in the past, at the rate of $15.00 a teaching month, as long as it is provided by law.

Ottawa, October 16, 1923.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the payment of salaries of the teachers of the Indian day schools on the Queen Charlotte agency.

In reply I beg to say that the salary of Peter Hill and Alfred Adams, when engaged in the school, will be paid as formerly, namely, on receipt of a pay-list from you. I would point out, however, that at the end of each quarter, the usual quarterly return, showing the names of the pupils, days taught, etc., must be forwarded. This should be signed by the teacher. The September quarter return has not yet been received and, consequently, the salary of Peter Hill, for the month of September, cannot be paid.

As you have already been advised, Mr. Pamplin will be allowed salary at the rate of $800.00 per annum for the ten teaching months. It will not be necessary for you to forward monthly vouchers in his favour, as his salary will be paid quarterly on receipt of a return from the school.

The salary of Miss MacKay, teacher of the Skidegate Indian Day School, will be forwarded in the future as in the past, to the Treasurer of the Methodist Missionary Society.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
