Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

For the past six fiscal years, the Department of Indian Affairs has paid bonus at a flat rate of $150 each to Indian day school teachers. This practice was confirmed by Orders in Council dated 11th November, 1922, (P.C. 2341) and 21st June, 1924, (P.C. 1036).

Order in Council dated 6th May, 1925, (P.C. 1/712) provided new ranges of compensation with a view to the discontinuance of the cost of living bonus. Section B. of Section II of Civil Service Regulations re bonus and salary, approved by this Order in Council, appears to be sufficient authority for adding $150 to the salary of each teacher and I propose, with your approval, to make payments for the June quarter at the new rate.

I understand that Miscellaneous Vote No. 492 (which provides, subject to the approval of the Treasury Board, for salaries, reclassification, revision, promotions and increases) includes the item which was placed in our Supplementary Estimates to care for this increase to Indian day school teachers. At the end of the fiscal year, arrangements will have to be made for a transfer from this Vote to Indian Education of the funds necessary to pay such increase.

Russell J. Turner

MEMO. FOR FILE.

I have made a study of payments that have been made to teachers of Indian day schools upon retirement. The Department has decided that, whereas they appear to be in the class known as 'temporary Civil Servants', they are not eligible for superannuation under the 1924 Act. (See file #129-19).

I have learned that in the past there have been payments of a gratuity or retiring allowance in the case of 9 teachers. (See list attached). The amounts of the payments varied from 2 to 6 months' salary. Vouchers were prepared showing that the payments were retiring allowances or gratuities. No authority was secured other than that of the Deputy Superintendent General, and on one or two occasions that of the Hon. the Minister. The Auditor General to my knowledge - and I have carefully examined the files - has never questioned these payments.

It was the Department's wish to give a gratuity in the case of the teacher of the Skawah Indian School, who suffered from ill-health during the last few months of his incumbency, and died during the summer months. Mr. Paget and Mr. MacKenzie are of the opinion that authority is necessary before any payment of more than 2 months' salary can be given. I phoned Mr. Douglas, of the Auditor General's Department, and he concurs in this opinion.

On at least three occasions (see list attached), teachers of Indian day schools, who have given long service, have been granted not only two months' gratuity but an annuity. Authority of His Excellency in Council was secured for each of these actions.

Russell T. Ferrier
Supt. of Indian Education.
December 28, 1925.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

Lyman W. Fisher was teacher at the Rock Settlement Day School up to June 30th, last. He was replaced by a professionally qualified worker. Mr. Fisher has been employed by this Department continuously since January 1, 1906—a period of 19½ years. His service might be characterized as faithful. He is now 45 years of age.

Mr. Fisher has applied for a gratuity and he wishes it applied on a Soldier Settlement loan of $1500 which he took over in 1922. He has made payments on this loan to the amount of $384.89. There was due and payable in November an instalment balance of $57.66 and when this is paid there will be a total owing of $1041.04.

I wish to recommend that a gratuity of $260, which is equivalent to four months' salary, be allowed. Precedent for such a payment is established by eight gratuities, equivalent to more than two months' salary, in the case of retiring teachers of Indian day schools since 1907—which payments have not been questioned.

Supt. of Indian Education.

RURAL SCHOOL SALARIES.

To those not familiar with such matters, it will come almost incredible that teachers in the rural schools of the Ottawa region are paid a maximum "salary" of $200 a year, as just stated by Professor Cloutier of McGill at a meeting of lay teachers of Hull County on Wednesday. None is more essential to the school teacher than to do essential work; teachers have more directly to do parents' teaching the lives of the young people than any other person they come in contact with. The least that can be expected from that teacher who paid a living wage. The salary mentioned is not that it is a mere pittance and alone will not ensure a decent standard of living.

How do these responsible for such conditions expect young women to take up such a calling? The teaching profession under such circumstances is not a career but a martyrdom. And what of the children? Is it to be expected that they will receive the instruction they need to fit them for after-life work? Their teachers are offered such beggarly remuneration! It can only be assumed that these responsible look upon the education of children as an irksome subjection to the frivolous belief shared by members of most communities that schooling is the right of every young person.

Conditions, however, are not a great deal better in other parts of the country, for in Ontario and the West the salaries of rural teachers range from $400 to only $600 a year. One can only express admiration for the self-sacrifice of the teachers who are under these conditions and hope that any move to better their lot will be crowned with success.

Dear Mr. Harrold,-

Pursuant to our telephone conversation, I am writing to indicate the average salaries paid to the lowest grade of certificated teachers of rural schools in the different provinces of Canada. Your editorial in "The Citizen" of January 7th stated that in Ontario and the West, the salaries of rural teachers ranged from $400.00 to only $500.00 a year. I hope you will be able to correct the impression left by these figures, which should be nearly doubled to be in harmony with the facts.

The information in this writing has been secured from the latest "Annual Survey of Education in Canada", a publication of the Dominion Bureau of Statistics, Department of Trade and Commerce. The period covered in this publication is the academic year ended June 30, 1926, except in the case of Quebec, Ontario and Manitoba. The period for Quebec and Ontario is one year earlier and for Manitoba, the academic year ended June 30, 1925. Of course, my remarks concerning teachers and their classification referred to those in elementary schools only.

The Maritimes.

In Prince Edward Island, there are three classes of teachers and the average salary of all (male and female) in the lowest class was $405.00. In Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, there are five classes and the average salary of the lowest was $409.00 and $411.00 in these provinces respectively. It can be stated that the average salary for rural schools in the Maritimes would be higher than these figures indicate, for many better qualified teachers are employed in these schools and, in this present study, their salaries are not taken into account.
Quebec.

In Quebec, there are three classes of teachers and the average salary of female lay teachers of the lowest class in Roman Catholic rural schools was $277.00. In Protestant schools, the average for this class of teacher was $356.00.

Ontario.

There are three classes of certificate in Ontario and the average salary of female teachers in rural Public Schools was $389.00. For Separate Schools this figure for the lowest grade of teachers is not available, but the average salary of all female teachers in Separate rural schools was $307.00.

Prairie Provinces.

In these provinces, there are three classes of teachers, and in Manitoba, excluding consolidated schools where higher salaries are paid, there were 281 teachers (male and female) in rural schools receiving less, and 1542 receiving more, than $900.00. In Saskatchewan and Alberta, the average salary of the lowest class of teachers (male and female), in rural schools, was $1001.00 and $1002.00, respectively. I wish to point out here that, in Alberta, there are very few of the lowest class of teachers employed, so that the average salary of rural school teachers in this province would be much higher than the figure given.

British Columbia.

The lowest individual salary paid to a teacher in rural and Assisted schools in British Columbia was $750.00 — the highest, $2550.00, and the average salary for the teachers of this class of schools was $1085.00. I might add here that the average salary of teachers in organized rural municipalities was $1509.00.

I regret that the foregoing could not be placed in the form of a tabular statement so that a moment's attention would enable the cursory reader to grasp the significance of the figures. The different methods of the Provincial Statisticians make this impossible.

Yours very truly,

R.W. Harold, Esq.,
The Citizen,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT,

Mrs. A. Beauvais, who has taught for the Department continuously from September, 1895, has been retired as from the 30th ultimo. It is desired to deal as generously as possible in her case.

Prior to 1924, three teachers of Indian day schools, who had given long service, were superannuated under the Calder Act. The provisions of this Act are no longer effective. In addition, seven teachers were given from three to six months' retiring leave, and, as far as I am aware, these payments were not questioned.

The Superannuation Act of 1924 evidently changed the situation. You will remember that the Department decided it was not proper to admit our teachers to the privileges enjoyed by a permanent Civil Servant. This action was taken for good and sufficient reasons, which still obtain. In 1925, however, when we granted four months' retiring leave to Levi Dortater, the Auditor General wrote: "Retiring leave with pay may be granted only by the Civil Service Commission and for a period not exceeding 60 days. I shall be obliged if you will let me know the authority under which this payment to Levi Dortater has been made." The Department replied in part: "I regret that I can find no authority in this connection". I believe the only adequate authority would have been a special vote.

From 1924 to 1927, several teachers of Indian day schools, who had served the Department faithfully, received two months' retiring leave. These payments were not questioned. I now believe, however, that these payments of two months' gratuity from 1924 to 1927 were really without adequate authority. Section 75 of the Civil Service Regulations makes no provision for retiring leave in the case of those who have not been given permanent status.

Pursuant to an Order in Council in June, 1927, concerning superannuation regulations, I find that there was an additional Order passed on July 4th of that year (P.C. 5/1916). This gives authority for retiring leave to "temporary employees who have been employed in permanent positions under departmental authority since prior to the 24th of May, 1918, but whose permanent status has never been confirmed". The retiring leave mentioned is as provided by Section 75 of the Civil Service Regulations as extended by the Order in Council. Section 75 allows 2 months retiring
leave, and, in the case of persons who are being retired under the provisions of the Superannuation and Retirement Act, 1906, or under the provisions of Section 5, Subsection a I and a II, of the C. S. S. A., 1927, retiring leave as follows:

10 to 15 years continuously - 3 months.
15 " 20 " " - 4 "
20 " 25 " " - 5 "
25 years or over " - 6 "

I believe it is quite in order, under authority of this Order in Council, to give retiring leave of from one to six months to teachers of Indian day schools who have been in our employ prior to May 24, 1918. With your concurrence, I propose to allow Mrs. Beaupre six months' gratuity.

In the case of those teachers who were not employed before May 24, 1918, but who now or in the future have given 5, 10 or 15 years' service, there appears to be no authority for even 2 months' retiring leave, but, as we have always granted such without official criticism from any source, I think we can safely continue the practice for worthy teachers.

Russell T. Ferrier
Supt. of Indian Education.

Memorandum:

I have had conversations with both the Civil Service Commission and the Auditor General, with reference to sick leave for long term temporary employees. I find that Section 65 of the Civil Service Regulations indicates that permanent and temporary employees are subject to the same regulations in this matter. Sick leave is at the rate of 1/2 days per month of continuous service and is cumulative.

The undetermined status of "Teacher - Indian Day School", of course, makes it impossible for the Civil Service Commission or the Auditor General to rule in the matter, but it is understood that the Deputy Minister may give this leave, up to six months, in any fiscal year, on the production of satisfactory evidence of disability (Sec. 67).

Dear Madam,

I have your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to qualifications and salaries of the teachers in certain Ontario Indian day schools.

The information regarding qualifications is not contained in any of our printed reports but, if there is any special reason why you require the details, I shall be glad to give your request consideration. As you may be aware, Indian schools do not come under the provincial departments. They are controlled solely by this Department. In nearly every case, they were started many years ago by one or other of the missionary societies or orders who are associated with us in Indian work. Some of the teachers have no professional certificates but have a special training in institutions conducted by their orders or societies and have long experience in our work.

With reference to salaries, they vary from $800 to $1,000 for the ten teaching months.

If the Department can be of any further help, please let me know.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: PER CAPITA GRANTS AT Indian Residential Schools.

There was a quickening of interest in the education of the Indians of Canada in the eighties, and, in 1892, the Government had to give serious consideration to a system of financing the residential schools. The number of boarding and industrial schools had become greatly increased, particularly in western Canada. Order in Council of October 22, 1892, authorized the per capita grant method of financing the industrial schools. For some time, grants had been given to boarding schools. At this time, the grants varied from $60 to $145, the average grant for the next 20 years being $86.00.

In 1911, in answer to the pressure from the Churches for larger grants for the boarding schools, there was prepared a schedule by geographical divisions and types of buildings, and a formal agreement was made between the Department and the management of the boarding schools. This was in effect from April first, 1911, to April first, 1916. The average grant, including that paid to industrial schools for this period, was $115.00.

In 1919, there was a bonus or a flat increase of $10 in the rate and in 1921, an additional $10 - a total bonus of $20, making the average grant for all schools $135.00. In 1924, this bonus was incorporated in the regular scale of grants.

Pursuant to a church delegation in January, 1926, there was an upward revision and an effort to deal more fairly with the rural school, the one remote from markets and the institution where farming and other facilities were poor. This revision was continued for five years, and, last year (1931), the average per capita grant paid to Indian residential schools in Canada amounted to $172.00.

It might be noted that, when the largest increases were made in the per capita grants, it was at a time of inflation and prosperity (1911, 1920 and 1926). During the present period of depression, it has been found necessary, in the interests of economy, to make a flat decrease in the per capita grants, of 10%, which will make the average $155. However, the dollar today purchases more than it has done any time since the War, so there should be no real hardship. Of course, any lowering of the grants means poorer food, and clothing and less efficient academic and vocational and academic training. It will also have effect on minor repairs and painting to our buildings.

(Sgd.) Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Reverend Sir:

As Mr. Phelan told you when he called on you last week, it is the intention of the Department to pay the salaries of teachers of Indian day schools monthly. This new system will commence at the end of the present month.

The salaries of the teachers of the Indian Day Schools mentioned on the attached list have in the past been forwarded to the Treasurer of the United Church of Canada. This new procedure will involve issuing a separate cheque to each teacher and forwarding the same from here to the teacher's address. The Regulations now require that all salary cheques should be paid direct to the teacher concerned, unless Power of Attorney has been received from the teacher, authorising payment to some other party.

As the present system of issuing cheques to the United Church Missionary Society has been in operation for so many years, the Department did not wish to make any change without advising you. I trust that your Society will have no objection to the new procedure, which is being adopted for the sole reason of facilitating our work.

You will note that I am not including on the enclosed list the seasonal schools. Payment of the amount due for teaching services at this class of schools, conducted under the auspices of the United Church, will be paid in the future, as in the past, to your Treasurer. Possibly, there are one or two schools on the attached list, for which you would also prefer having the cheques issued to your Treasurer; and, if so, you should advise me, and the Department will comply with your wishes.

Your obedient servant,

April 23rd, 1934.

My dear Mr. Sutherland,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th inst., re direct payment of Salaries of teachers in Indian Day schools and that monthly.

Where the Department's grant constitutes the entire salary of the teacher as in the case of the teacher at the Jack River School, the teacher will no doubt, welcome the change and it will not affect the Church one way or other, as in the case of Anglican Missions the Bishop will continue in the case of vacancies to make the nomination of a suitable person to the Department.

In the case of schools, such as Split Lake and Hollowwater River, the change will somewhat complicate the payment of salaries due the teachers since they receive stipend at a specific rate from our headquarters of which the salary given by the Department forms a part, they could of course give me the power of attorney and direct payment to be made as formerly. If the method you advise becomes operative at the end of this month cheques from your office would hardly reach either teacher as the spring break-up is due and mails will be interrupted for at least a month.

One advantage of the former method of paying through the Church authorities is the fact that the payments of the department in support of Indian Education in the Day Schools of the Missions are published in the annual financial statements of the Church and credit is thus given the Indian Department of the Dominion Government for the valuable help thus given.

Kindly let me know the course you finally decide upon and keep me informed as to your payments if made direct so that I may adjust our payments accordingly.

Yours faithfully,

J.D. Sutherland, Esq.

BOARD OF HOME MISSIONS

The United Church of Canada

Toronto, April 24, 1934

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Re Method of Payment - Salaries of Day School Teachers.

I did not reply immediately to your communication of April 9th concerning this matter, because I wanted to discuss it with the Indian and Oriental Committee of the Board of Home Mission, which held a long session in connection with our recent annual meeting.

Rightly or wrongly, there is a growing feeling on the part of our missionaries and their representatives on the Board that the Government plans to take away from the Missionary Societies of the Churches the right to nominate teachers for Indian Day Schools. This feeling is very pronounced and exceedingly vocal over our whole British Columbia Conference. We had before us a very strong resolution which was passed by the British Columbia Conference last May. After due consideration, the Committee recommended a resolution which is copied herewith, and it was unanimously adopted by the Board:

"That we reaffirm our conviction that it is in the interests of both the educational and missionary work on Indian Missions that the Church should retain the right to nominate teachers for Indian Day Schools, and that the Secretaries be asked to call a Conference with other Churches engaged in Indian work, with a view to making representations to the Department of Indian Affairs asking for assurance that no infringement of this right is contemplated."

"We further recommend that the teachers nominated should possess the following qualifications:

1) Must be missionary minded.
2) Must have adequate professional qualifications.
3) Must be old enough to appreciate the problems involved in living on an Indian reserve."
(4) Must be able to work harmoniously with others.
(5) Must, preferably, be members of the United Church of Canada."

There are some difficulties, so far as our method of administration is concerned, in acceding to the request of the Department. The fact that you have decided to pay day school teachers monthly will be no advantage to our teachers, because it has been our custom to pay them nothing no matter how long we had to wait for the Department's cheques. It is out of our hands entirely the determination of the salary which is to be paid. For example, when I raised with you a year ago the question of the salary of Miss Frances Patterson, who was being appointed to Port Simpson, I was told that it was impossible for the Government to increase it because of a certain Order in Council. By re-arranging salaries at two or three places in British Columbia, we were able to pay Miss Patterson on a basis commensurate with her experience and teaching ability. That she has already completely transformed the Port Simpson school is proof of the wisdom of her appointment.

In addition, a good many of the teachers in the list which you enclosed are missionary-teachers. For some strange reason, which I have never been able to understand, the Department of Indian Affairs discriminates against a missionary-teacher in the setting of his salary - no matter how well qualified he may be otherwise. In spite of the fact that in the last four years we have changed the status and qualifications of more than two-thirds of our teachers, and in spite of the fact that these missionary-teachers today are either experienced teachers in middle life or university graduates with technical educational training, the Department still continues to set the salaries on a lower scale, and the Board of Home Missions has to give a very considerable additional amount in most cases, in order to obtain their services.

If it is merely a matter of getting a statement from each of our teachers that they prefer to be paid through this office, that will be comparatively easy to obtain. If the Treasury Board insists that the cheques must be made out henceforth in the name of the individual, then I do not see why our office should not be the post office address of these teachers, and we could add the additional amount which we find it necessary to pay them in order to secure workers of their calibre.

I hope to be in Ottawa on Thursday and will be glad to discuss this matter with you at length. We have no desire to be obstinate, but the situation so far as we are concerned is decidedly awkward.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton.

MEMORANDUM

The Honourable the Superintendent General -

I am forwarding herewith for your information a copy of letter received recently from Reverend Kenneth J. Beaton, Secretary, Board of Home Missions of The United Church of Canada.

In his letter Mr. Beaton submits two objections to Departmental policy:

First. He insists very strongly, as you will note upon the alleged right of the various Church organizations to nominate teachers for Indian Day Schools. In the appointment of Day School teachers the Department has been guided very largely by nominations made by the Church missionary organizations. However, this has always been conceded rather a privilege than a right.

Second. Reverend Mr. Beaton objects to the various Day School teachers employed by the Department being paid directly by cheques through the Comptroller of the Treasury Department. The practice has been in the past to make a cheque in favour of the missionary society in payment of all the teachers affiliated with that particular body. With this practice which Mr. Beaton wishes to continue, I am entirely in disagreement and feel that the position taken by the Comptroller of the Treasury, that cheques should be sent to individual teachers, is perfectly sound and one that should be adhered to.

Deputy Superintendent General.
May 8th, 1934.

Dear Mr. Beaton:

I have given careful consideration to your letter of the 26th ultimo, and it has been decided to forward the salaries of teachers of Indian Day Schools direct. As you were previously informed, all salaries will be paid monthly in future.

As I intimated to you when you were in my office recently, the question of the method of appointment of teachers is the subject of correspondence between this Department and the Civil Service Commission. A definite decision in this regard has not yet been reached.

I have noted particularly the paragraph in your letter in which you complain of a discrimination against missionary teachers in the matter of salary. I agree with you that the salaries of qualified missionary teachers should not be on a lower scale. Unfortunately, present conditions and regulations do not permit the Department to make any re-adjustment in salaries. The matter, however, will be kept in mind, and as soon as financial conditions warrant, the necessary adjustments will be made in the salaries of this class of teachers.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. McKenzie:

I understand that a change has been made by your Department in the manner of paying the salaries to the teachers for our Day Schools at Selkirk and Moosehide.

Formerly a cheque was sent each quarter to the Diocese but I understand the arrangement now is that at the end of each month a cheque is sent to the teacher at these two places. I am writing to ask if it would be possible to have the cheque made out to the Diocese as formerly. The Missionaries at those two points, who are also the teachers of the day schools, receive a salary considerably larger than that provided by the Dept., and this salary is guaranteed to them irrespective of whether the Dept. makes any payment or not, and it would be much easier for us if the cheques could be made out to the Diocese. If, however, the Dept. feels the proper procedure to be that of sending the cheque direct to the individual teacher we shall, of course, be quite satisfied to have that method carried out.

With regard to the day schools at Carmacks, Champagne and Teslin, is it your intention to follow a similar procedure here?

I shall be glad to hear from you regarding this matter.

Yours sincerely,

Ottawa, July 9, 1934.

Right Reverend Sir:

With reference to Your Lordship's letter of the 23rd ultimo, it is regretted that you were not previously advised regarding the monthly payment of the salaries of the teachers of the Selkirk and Moosehide Indian Day Schools.

Present regulations require that salaries of teachers of Indian day schools that are in regular operation should be paid direct to the teachers, and since April of this year salaries are being paid monthly. In view of the regulations mentioned, the Department desires to continue monthly payment of salaries to the teachers of the Selkirk and Moosehide Schools.

The amounts due for the seasonal schools which have been authorized will be paid in the same manner as in the past, viz., the cheques will be issued in favour of the Diocese of Yukon and sent to the Financial Secretary, Mr. A. Goldrick, Dawson, Yukon.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Dear Sir,

The following September quarter returns of the residential schools appear to contain the following errors:

- **Birtle:** Page 1 adds to 2305 instead of 2306 resulting in an overpayment of 36 cents.
- **Cowessess:** Average attendance should be 78.17 instead of 78.16. Underpayment of 36 cents.
- **Thunderchild:** Page 5 adds to 10039; average attendance is therefore 109.11. Underpayment of $7.23.
- **St. Paul's Hostel:** Average attendance should be 18.13. Overpaid 53 cents.
- **Alert Bay:** Page 6 adds to 14046 instead of 13956 resulting in an underpayment of $37.49.
- **Port Simpson:** The payment would appear to be $992.53 instead of $966.85. Underpaid $25.67.
- **St. Mary's:** Page 1 adds to 2139 instead of 2158. No overpayments however as per capita at 125 only.
- **Fort Resolution:** Adds to 5718 instead of 3717. Apparently underpaid $924.38.

It would appear that many of these errors in the first instance were made by the school authorities resulting in a loss of revenue to themselves. I would suggest that you impress on them the desirability of correct returns from their standpoint as well as from that of the Department.

Yours truly,

J.D. Sutherland, Esq.,

Sir:

I have to inform you that His Lordship the Bishop of Caledonia has nominated the services of Mr. W. Thorman as teacher of the summer school which it is proposed to open during the coming summer for the benefit of the Indian children at Tahltan. The appointment of Mr. Thorman is approved, with salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month. It is understood that this school will be opened as early as possible in May next, and will continue for a period of approximately five months.

The Department understands that suitable classroom accommodation will be provided by the church authorities. The classroom supplies considered necessary will be forwarded in due time.

I would request that you give Mr. Thorman every possible assistance in his work and in encouraging a regular attendance of the Indian children of school age.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Replying to your letter No. 1-1-3 dated October 12th, in reference to the operation of Day Schools in this Agency, I have to advise as follows:

Dear Mr. Hoey:

We have been consulting the Auditor General's Report to see what the trend has been in the salaries of Indian day school teachers in recent years, and have run into a difficulty.

In the last couple of years most of the salaries are indicated as for ten months, whereas back in 1930 they were mainly for nine months, and in 1926 mainly for twelve months. The significance of this different number of months in different years puzzles us. We wonder if it just means that the annual salary in some years was paid in ten instalments, while in others it was paid in nine or twelve instalments. Our particular concern is whether the stated salary, regardless of the number of months involved, represents the amount earned in a year.

If you could help us out on this point we would appreciate it. It would help us in a calculation we are making on the trend of earnings in the teaching profession as a whole.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant regarding certain returns for the quarters ending September 1 and December 31, 1937 I trust the following explanations will be satisfactory:

1. Sioux Lookout Residential School

On checking this return it is found that a mistake was made in computing the amount of the grant and the underpayment of $3.92 will be allowed when paying the March quarter grant.

2. Blood Residential School

The aggregate attendance as shown by this return for the quarter ended December 31, 1937 was 13,266 days. This was more than the authorized pupilage which is 140 pupils. 140 pupils at 92 days gives an aggregate attendance of 12,880 days. Deducting the period taken for Christmas holidays; namely, 375 days, left a balance of 12,505 days and gives an average attendance of 135.92 for which grant should have been allowed. The grant due on the basis of average attendance of 135.92 would be $5,326.36.

However, at the time the grant was actually paid a mistake was made in computing the aggregate attendance. You will note that in the pencil entry on the return 140 x 92 is shown as 12,600 which is incorrect.

The average was computed on this incorrect aggregate and as a result the school was only paid $5,207.23. There is a balance due of $119.13 which will be allowed on the March quarter grant.

G. J. Allan, Esq.,
Chief Examiner, 46th Branch,

With the approval of the Director it was decided some time ago to allow the full pupilage at the 5 schools provided the average attendance as shown on the returns warranted this procedure. The increased number allowed at Wabasca should really have been allowed at some other school which showed a higher average but the total grant allowed the 5 schools for the September quarter did not exceed 475 and, therefore, no overpayment was made for this quarter.

Memorandum:

DR. MCGILL:

You are, no doubt, aware that in recent years certain deductions were made by the Department in the annual per capita allowances to residential schools.

The records indicate that in the fiscal year 1932-33 the deduction was 10%. In the years 1933-34 and 1934-35 this was increased to 15%. In the year 1935-36 a 10% restoration took place so that during the years 1935-36, 1936-37, 1937-38 and 1938-39 the actual net deduction has amounted to 5%.

The church authorities have been vigorously opposed to these reductions. Last year a deputation representing these churches interviewed the Minister, with the object of having the per capita allowances restored to the original figure. It is my understanding that arrangements are now under way to have a similar delegation interview the Minister and other members of the Government toward the end of this month. In view of this fact, I considered it advisable to submit an analysis of the actual cost to the Department of maintaining residential schools and also a comparison of this cost with the cost of maintaining somewhat similar institutions by provincial governments and by private organizations. The following figures indicate the actual cost to the Government of residential schools for a six year period, less interest and depreciation charges. The figures include the ordinary per capita grants less 5%; $20,000 per year medical costs, dental care, etc.; approximately $20,000 for text books, stationery supplies, etc., and the cost of repairs, equipment, etc., is also included: -

It will be noted that only in one year - the year ended March 31, 1932, did the cost per pupil per annum at residential schools exceed $200. This cost may appear somewhat high when compared with the cost of instruction at Indian schools but is exceptionally low when compared with the per capita costs, less interest charges and depreciation at other institutions. From receipt of a statement dated October 28, 1936 from the Manitoba Department of Education, in which figures are submitted with respect to the cost of operating the Manitoba School for the Deaf, Tuxedo, Man., and the Manitoba School for Boys, Portage la Prairie, Man. These statistics indicate that the cost per pupil per annum at the Manitoba School for the Deaf during the last calendar year amounted to $642.40. The Manitoba School for Boys, Portage la Prairie, operated in conjunction with a large farm, shows a cost per pupil per annum of $550. This is a co-educational school. The boys' attendance range in age from 15 to 18. The pupils in attendance at the Manitoba School for the Deaf range in age between 6 and 17 years. Depreciation charges or interest charges on capital outlay are not included in the figures submitted by the Manitoba officials.

The Knowles School for Boys, North Kildonan, Man., is a privately operated institution for boys but is subject to supervision under the Community Chest Advisory Board of the city of Winnipeg. The age range of the boys in attendance -
attendance at this school is between 8 and 17 years. The per capita cost at this institution - depreciation charges included - for the year 1937 amounted to $262.44.

The St. Norbert Children's Aid Society (infancy to 5 years only) is a Roman Catholic institution, established for the care of Roman Catholic orphans. The per capita costs at this institution for the year 1937 amounted to $294.84.

The St. Joseph's Orphanage, Manitoba, also a Catholic institution (boys 5 years and up) shows for the year 1937 per capita cost of $320.10.

In the Child Welfare Act (province of Alberta) the minimum rate for the maintenance of a child committed to either the Provincial Superintendent of Neglected Children or to the Children's Aid Society is $1.00 per day; in the province of Ontario the rate is 75¢ a day; in the province of Saskatchewan 50¢; and in the province of British Columbia $4.00 per week. While there is no minimum rate set in the Manitoba Child Welfare Act, the following are the rates of maintenance granted by the Juvenile Court Judge of Winnipeg:

"In view of all the submissions presented, the Court hereby fixes the following rates for the maintenance of children committed by this Court under Part IV of the Child Welfare Act of Manitoba:

To the Director of Child Welfare ... ... 68¢"

Mr. Phelan, Chief of the Training Division, visited the Chilocco Indian Residential School, Oklahoma, during his holiday period of last year. This is an Indian residential school, established for the education of Indian pupils by the United States Government and operated solely as a government institution. There was at the time of Mr. Phelan's visit an enrolment of 650 pupils. Special provision has been made at this school for vocational instruction, farming, auto mechanics, printing, tailoring, domestic science, etc. The cost per pupil (less depreciation and interest charges) is $350.

The Child Welfare League of America, in one of its recent publications, states:

"More inquiries are made to this office regarding per capita costs for children in Child Welfare institutions than any other single subject. The most common inquiry is one that asks us to make a comparison between the cost of child care in a foster family home and the cost in a foster institution."
The following costs may be noted:

A well equipped institution in an Eastern State (U.S.) with an adequate institutional staff as well as case work and psychiatric service - $341. per child per annum.

A small foster home agency with good standards in a city of nearly one million inhabitants - $313.

A well equipped and standardized children's agency in a city of more than one million inhabitants - $508.

A good sized foster home agency of many years standing and with good standards in one of the largest cities in the U.S. - $405.

You will observe that the cost of maintaining pupils in our Indian residential schools is substantially lower than the cost of maintaining children in the institutions referred to in the preceding paragraphs. A number of factors are accountable, in my judgment, for these lower costs:

(1) The existing agreement or understanding with the church authorities, whereby our residential schools are operated by the churches;

(2) Members of religious Orders, men and women imbued with missionary zeal, are prepared to serve in these institutions for salaries that would not be acceptable to the average social service worker or public school teacher;

(3) Fully equipped farms are operated in conjunction with practically all our residential schools. The revenue from these farms, particularly when crops are good, tend to keep down maintenance costs;

(4) It is my understanding that a number of Women's Missionary Societies and other such auxiliary church organizations supply a number of residential schools with clothing and other articles for the comfort of the pupils, without cost. In the case of the Church of England Schools, the freight charges on these supplies are paid by the Department;

(5) Substantial grants are made by the Home Mission Boards of certain churches for the upkeep of residential schools. The last audit report, dated March 1, 1928, on the Birtle Residential School (Presbyterian) shows that the church grants made to this school for the year under review amounted to $1,945.75, plus a grant of $5,300 paid in cheques for the salaries of the Principal and teaching staff.
A fixed per capita grant is in no sense a satisfactory method of financing residential schools. This method lacks the elasticity and flexibility necessary to meet the wide variation that takes place from time to time in the cost of essential supplies. The Provinces in their desire to be fair to Child Welfare institutions have in a number of cases extended to Juvenile Court Judges the right to fix the maintenance costs from year to year. I have secured the following figures from the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission of the Anglican Church in Canada:

You will note particularly the increase in the cost of flour during the year 1938 when compared with the cost of the same commodity during the year 1935.

It is my personal opinion that provision should be made this year for the restoration of the 5% reduction in per capita allowances. I think this restoration might take place on the understanding that the schools would assume responsibility for the payment of certain charges now borne by the Government, which do not amount to much in the aggregate but the payment of which is somewhat annoying in that it involves us in a great deal of correspondence, checking of vouchers, etc. I have in mind the payment of night watchmen at certain schools where the fire hazard is considered great. This amounts to $10,000 annually. I might mention also the payment of the freight charges on clothing and supplies purchased by missionary bodies and sent forward to the residential schools. I should like to include also the transportation costs of children to and from residential schools. In as much, however, as provision is made for the payment of these charges in the Act, I do not know that the churches would be prepared to assume this cost for the time being at least.

It is of the utmost importance, also, that the restoration should be made on the understanding that the Churches will provide greater facilities for manual training, instruction in handicraft, auto mechanics, weaving, etc. A great many of our residential schools have not the equipment -
equipment necessary to undertake a worthwhile course in vocational instruction.

A number of years ago (1911) the Government and the Churches entered into an agreement with respect to the operation of residential schools. This agreement expired in 1916 and was not renewed. I am not of the opinion that it is necessary to enter into a formal agreement with the Churches at this time, but I do suggest that an understanding be reached with the Church Authorities whereby steadily increasing emphasis will be placed on the importance of vocational instruction at residential schools. An understanding should also be reached with respect to recruiting on Indian reserves. Our inspectors and a number of our Indian agents feel that they should be consulted before recruiting is undertaken on a reserve, and it seems to me that this request is a reasonable one. Our School Inspector in British Columbia informs me that a large number of pupils are taken from year to year from districts or reserves where Indian day schools are in operation and enrolled at residential schools hundreds of miles from their homes. We have attempted to restrict this practice during the last year or two, but the practice itself is wholly unjustifiable and should cease.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Per Capita Grants,
Indian Residential Schools

Provision was made in the 1939-40 estimates for the payment of per capita grants to Indian residential schools. The actual appropriation for the year amounted to $1,895,651. It now appears that this sum is insufficient to pay in full the per capita grants for the quarter ended December 31, 1939. It is estimated that an additional amount of $60,000 will be necessary to meet these payments.

The records indicate that until the fiscal year 1932-33 the amount necessary to pay per capita grants to residential schools, based on 100% attendance at these institutions, was voted by Parliament from year to year. A review of departmental appropriations was undertaken by the Government at that time, in an attempt to discover ways and means of effecting economies. The average attendance at that time was 94.4% and the appropriation for the succeeding year was based on the assumption that the average attendance in that year would not exceed this figure. The appropriation for the year 1939-40 was based on an average attendance of 92.24%. While actual figures are not available, the officials feel that there has been a substantial improvement in the average attendance during the year. In addition to this, we have been called upon to make greater provision than was made in former years for supernumerary pupils. These pupils are usually orphans or children deserted by their parents, for whom institutional care -
care has to be provided. The practice for some years has been to send them to a residential school, on the understanding that this school will be paid a grant for their care until the end of the academic year, when such pupils must be absorbed into the regular enrolment of the institution. We have at this date an attendance at residential schools of 403 pupils more than those for whom provision was made in the regular per capita grant of this year. A substantial majority of these pupils are cared for by the churches without cost to the Department. A certain number, however, are receiving supernumerary grants.

I should like to discuss with you at your convenience ways and means of securing the amount necessary to meet our full obligation of this year to residential schools. It is in my judgment highly desirable that these grants should be paid at the earliest possible date.

Director.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL

In response to your request, I am sending forward herewith statement indicating the increases that have taken place in per capita grant payments to Indian residential schools during the fiscal years 1937-38, 1938-39, 1939-40 and the proposed increases for the fiscal year 1940-41.

The records here indicate that practically all of these increases were made in conformity with instructions received by this Division from the office of the Minister. There were, however, certain adjustments made by this Division. These adjustments were made to correct conditions at certain residential schools, the principals of which were experiencing difficulty in securing their full quota of pupils, and in the interests of certain other schools that were making provision for a larger number of pupils than those for which the per capita grant was being paid.

In the year 1927-28 the number eligible for per capita grant payments at the Muscowequan school (R.C.), Sask., was reduced by 15 and increases were allowed at Pine Creek, Sask., (5); St. Philips (5); and Squamish (5). In the year 1938-39 the number eligible for per capita grant payments at the Cariboo school (R.C.), British Columbia, was reduced by 15 and the number allowed at Sr. Mary's Mission (R.C.), B.C., increased by 19 during the same year. In that year the grant paid at the Mount Elgin school (U.C.), Ontario, was increased from $150 to $160. This increase was made in response to a request received from the United Church, the officials of which pointed out that the Mohawk Institute was receiving per capita grant of $160, and that conditions and costs at both institutions were practically identical. In the fiscal year 1939-40 an increase of 5 was allowed at the Shingwauk school (C.E.), Ontario. The school at this point is a new building and the Principal at that time had an enrolment exceeding the number for which per capita grant was being allowed. In the fiscal year 1939-40 an adjustment took place at the Grouard (P.C.) school, Alberta. This adjustment was necessary to repay the church authorities for the construction of the new fireproof wing built by them at Grouard. The adjustment covers a 10 year period, specified in an agreement between the Minister and the church authorities. The increase of 5 at Ahousaht was due to the destruction of the Alberni school by fire and the transfer of these pupils to the Ahousaht school.

The proposed increase of 60 at Cross Lake (R.C.), Manitoba -
Manitoba, is due to the rebuilding of the school at that point and the increase of 20 at Sandy Bay is due to the reconstruction of the Sandy Bay school and the additional provision made for pupils in the two fire-proof wings constructed during the summer of 1939.

The total increases for the period under review, you will note, amount to $62,580, and the decreases to $4,515, leaving a net increase of $58,065.

I am sending forward also statement indicating the authorized pupilage, the amount voted for this purpose and the amount actually spent, for the years 1935-36 to 1939-40, inclusive. Both these statements should be studied and compared with the statement on the authorized enrolment at residential schools, recently prepared and now in your possession.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. H.W. McGill,
Dir. of Indian Affairs Branch.

When the Estimates for next fiscal year were under consideration in your absence shortly after the new year, the Minister at one time considered the possibility of making a general cut in the salaries of all Day School teachers. The reason for this was that he thought the Indian Day School teachers were paid on the whole a much higher salary than teachers in rural white schools. The suggestion was not put into effect as the reductions were made in other places. The Minister, however, suggested that the question of the salaries of Day School Teachers should be given further consideration for the purpose of seeing whether it might not be possible to effect economies, and at the same time make them more in line with similar salaries paid elsewhere.

I am returning herewith the report of the Research Committee of the Manitoba Teachers' Federation for the academic year 1938-39. You will notice that the average salary for the year 1938-39 was $539.60 and that for the year 1937-38 the average was only $513.26. These are certainly much lower than the average salaries of the Indian Day School teachers, although it is possible that the latter's period of service each year is longer.

The Minister thought it might be wise to consider establishing different classes for our teachers based, among other things, on the average number of pupils, the location of the school, the grades taught therein and the period of teaching, taking into consideration at the same time whether they are provided with living accommodation.

Will you please give the above consideration and let me have a full report for the information of the Minister.

C.W. Jackson,
Chief Executive Assistant.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Salaries of Indian Day School Teachers

I have for acknowledgment Mr. Jackson's memorandum of February 13 and also report of the Research Committee of the Manitoba Teachers' Federation for the academic year 1938-39, attached thereto.

I may state that immediately following a discussion of the 1940-41 estimates, which took place at your office a few weeks ago, a very thorough survey and investigation of the salaries paid Indian day school teachers was undertaken by the officials of the Welfare and Training Division. I am attaching hereto, for your information, a statement prepared by these officials. In this statement you will find the number of teachers in white rural schools for the year 1938 and the salaries paid to the teachers. You will note also the number of Indian day school teachers employed in each of the provinces. These teachers are classified and placed in the salary brackets allowed by this Department. I regret to say that in the case of the province of Quebec we have been unable at this date to secure a statement of the salaries paid to public school teachers.

In a discussion relating to the salaries that should be paid Indian day school teachers, one cannot be too careful to keep in mind a number of factors that have a direct bearing on the matter. The location of our Indian day schools is important. The officials of the United Church have on more than one occasion protested vigorously against the refusal of the Department to pay the transportation costs of the teachers nominated by the United -
the United Church for service at Indian day schools in outlying districts. These officials have pointed out that transportation costs to a number of these schools amount to $200. It is my understanding that in many cases this amount is advanced by the missionary Societies and later refunded at the rate of so much per month by the teachers. Indian day school teachers, unlike public school teachers, do not qualify for superannuation allowances and are subject to dismissal at 65. Our school teachers and the Teachers' Federation of the province of Saskatchewan have recently petitioned the Department to make provision for a teachers' superannuation fund. The obstacles, however, standing in the way of the creation of such a fund are in my judgment almost insurmountable.

In discussing Indian administration on a number of reserves with Indian agents who have visited Ottawa during the last two or three years, I have been deeply impressed by the assistance our Indian agents are able to give from our school teachers. Where an Indian agent lives 50 or 60 or 100 miles away from a reserve, he invariably communicates with the teacher in respect to relief allowances, complaints that have reached him from the Indians, the receipt of medical and other supplies, the best date or dates for the payment of twenty allowances, etc. We are not now making, nor have we at any time made, an allowance to teachers to cover the cost even of postage and other incidental expenses inseparable from these services. The emphasis that we are now placing on vocational instruction, carpentry work, elementary agriculture and hand-loom weaving, etc., is imposing additional burdens upon our teachers. Dr. Robertson has been insisting for a couple of years that only married teachers be employed and employed on the understanding that the man will assist in the promotion of agriculture on the reserve and that his wife will engage in the organization of women's clubs, etc. One of the most encouraging features of Indian administration at this date is in my judgment in evidence at Indian day schools where an increasingly large number of teachers have with very little encouragement or direction from the Department organized extra curricular activities on the reserve. References to these activities
and their success appeared from time to time in the monthly reports of the Superintendent of Welfare and Training.

It should be borne in mind also that Indian day schools are not subject to the same inspection as public schools, for the simple reason that many of them are almost inaccessible. This means that we are almost wholly dependent on the ability and willingness of the teacher in charge of the school to give of his or her best without direction or without the oversight ordinarily exercised by the trustees and inspectors in the case of public schools.

Drastic reductions have taken place in the salaries paid public school teachers during the period of the depression. The salaries paid in the case of a number of the provinces went far below the statutory minimum existing in such provinces with respect to waitresses, dish washers and the lowest classes of unskilled labour. At the same time the provincial educational authorities have been steadily elevating academic and professional standing, with the result that in a great many of the provinces now a teacher must have completed first year Arts or its equivalent, plus one year in normal school, plus three summer courses at a recognized summer school, before he or she can qualify for a permanent certificate. The result is exactly what one might expect: Canada is now confronted with a shortage of fully qualified teachers and in two of the provinces - Alberta and British Columbia - this shortage has become quite acute. We are not vitally concerned with the province of Alberta, as we have only one day school in that province, but we are unable at this date to secure the teachers necessary to conduct our schools in the province of British Columbia. Commissioner MacKay, in a letter to the Department dated January 10, 1940, states: "The second teacher has not been thus far secured for Gitladamix, and Bishop Rix informed me yesterday that he is continuing to make inquiries for a suitable teacher but at the moment had no one whom he could nominate. I may say that every effort is being made to secure qualified teachers for the existing vacancies in our Indian schools, all of which happen to be in the diocese of Caledonia. The Provincial Department of Education has been asked to assist, but owing to the scarcity of fully qualified teachers, the province is faced with a similar problem to our own and is
not at present in a position to help."

The Minister of Education for the province of Alberta, in his 1932 report, on page 8 states: "For the first time in years, a distinct shortage of teachers was experienced during the summer and fall of 1932. With an increase in registrations at our normal schools, however, it is our hope that supply and demand will come into balance again." My prediction is that unless there is a substantial increase in the salaries now paid to public school teachers throughout the Dominion, we shall during the next two or three years revert to the same conditions that existed in Canada during the last war and during the early twenties. In these times, provincial departments of education were compelled by force of circumstances to issue permits to at least 25% of the teachers, thus enabling them to take charge of schools, despite the fact that they had neither the academic standing nor the professional qualifications to undertake such work.

We have no seasonal schools at this date in operation in the provinces of Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Saskatchewan or Alberta. We have a few in operation in the other provinces. The desirability of abandoning these schools where the enrolment is 10 or less is now under consideration.

The suggestion made by the Minister and referred to by Mr. Jackson in the penultimate paragraph of his memorandum was adopted insofar as it was at all practicable to adopt it in fixing the salaries of teachers at the start of the 1932-40 academic year. There are certain difficulties, however, that confront the officials when they attempt to adopt the suggestion in the case of certain schools. For example, Indian Agent Hudson recommends the retirement of the present teacher at the Indian Island Day School in New Brunswick who has reached the age of 65, and the employment of a married man, who would be prepared to give direction to agricultural operations on the reserve and whose wife might be charged with the responsibility of organizing the women into a worthwhile women's group. Mr. Hudson assured us that only in this way can we hope to get a number of the Indians in his agency off relief. Ninety-nine per cent. of his Indians are now in receipt of relief allowances.
allowances from the Department. Should it be decided to adopt Mr. Hudson's suggestion, although the enrolment at this school is comparatively small, it would not be possible to secure a married man, trained in the sense that Mr. Hudson thinks he should be trained, for the salary paid the present teacher. The present salary amounts to $700 a year.

THE ADMINISTRATOR IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT Vote 163, the main estimates 1939-40, Department of Mines and Resources, provided an amount of $1,295,351.00 for per capita grants to Indian residential schools and that supplementary estimate No. 620 provided an amount of $76,000.00 for the same purpose, or a total amount of $1,371,351.00.

THAT the above amount was provided on the assumption that the average attendance at all Indian residential schools would not exceed 92.85% of the total authorized pupilage;

I have your memorandum of the 16th instant in reference to the above. The Minister will I am sure be interested in reading your comments.

The statement setting forth the salaries paid by all the Provinces to teachers in white rural schools would seem to indicate very clearly that our average salary is much higher, for example,

Province of Nova Scotia - Only 8 teachers out of 1416 receive salary of $800 or over, whereas the 11 teachers employed by the Department are all paid this sum or more.

Province of New Brunswick - Only 17 teachers out of 1426 receive salary of $800 or over, whereas 14 out of 15 of those employed by the Department receive this sum.

Province of Ontario - Only 1990 teachers out of 5284 receive salary of $800 or over, whereas 86 teachers out of a total of 103 employed by the Department receive this sum or more.

Province of Manitoba - Only 26 teachers out of a total of 1325 receive $800 or over, whereas 45 out of a total of 55 employed by the Department receive this sum or more.

Province of Saskatchewan - Only 67 teachers out of a total of 4255 receive $800 or more, whereas 24 out of a total of 31 employed by the Department receive this sum or more.

Province of British Columbia - The salaries appear to be more in line with those of the Department.
The statement does not show whether any allowance was made for the living accommodation provided to many of our teachers. It is assumed the comparison was based on the actual cash salary paid. If so, the difference would be greater.

You have set forth some good reasons why teachers at Indian Day Schools should be paid at a higher rate. It is not clear, however, that in fixing the salaries whether the special considerations you mention were kept in mind. Is it not a fact that only a small proportion of the teachers interest themselves actively in the welfare of the Indians and devote a good part of their time in doing the kind of work, for instance, that Dr. Robertson expects of them. If this should be true, is it not possible to compensate them for this extra service and at the same time reduce the salaries of other teachers who either because of their lack of interest or because the school is so situated that they are unable to, or it is not necessary for them to perform such services.

It is appreciated that it may be difficult to arrive at a definite scale but there would appear to be no good reason for paying all of our teachers on a scale higher than the average paid by the Provinces, unless they are all performing services not performed by the teachers in white rural schools. It is suggested that further consideration might be given to exploring the possibility of adjusting the salaries of those teachers who are not performing such services. Perhaps it might be possible to fix basic rates and when extra duties are placed upon any of the teachers, a special allowance made for the work involved.

C.W. Jackson,
Chief Executive Assistant.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Per Capita Grant Payments to Indian Residential Schools.

I desire to refer to my memorandum to you of January 30, 1940, with respect to obtaining additional funds to pay the per capita grants to Indian residential schools for the period ended December 31, 1938.

For the fiscal year 1938-39 an amount of $1,925,251.00 was voted for the payment of per capita grants. When the complete returns for the period were received, however, it was discovered that an additional amount of $62,662.88 was required to pay the grants in full to December 31, 1938. This additional amount has now been provided by Governor General's Warrant.

You are no doubt aware that there is a recognised pupilage at each of our residential schools. It was the practice of the Department until the fiscal year 1937-38 to provide in the estimates the total amount required to pay per capita grants in full and such amounts were based on the assumption that each school would have its authorized enrolment of pupils and that the attendance would average approximately 100%. For example, the total authorized pupilage at all residential schools for the fiscal year 1937-38 was 7,992 and the amount required to pay the per capita grant in full, $1,129,493.00. This was the amount voted. The amount actually disbursed because in that fiscal year was only $1,106,295.70. I should state that it was the practice in those years to make advances to a number of residential schools from the surplus funds available.

The Government, in an attempt to economize, decided -
decided in the fiscal year 1933-34 to vote only the amount sufficient to pay per capita grants on the assumption that the average attendance at residential schools would not exceed approximately 95%. For the fiscal year 1933-34, while the amount required to pay the per capita grants in full was $1,189,774.60, the amount actually voted was $1,126,750.00. In other words, for the first time in the history of the Department, the amount voted was insufficient to meet our financial obligations to the churches charged with the responsibility of operating our residential schools. However, inasmuch as payments had been made to certain residential schools in advance, it was not found necessary that year, or for a number of years, to ask for a supplementary estimate.

No attempt has been made in recent years to correct this condition or to revert to the policy in force prior to the fiscal year 1933-34. I have never been able to convince myself that the policy in effect since 1933-34 is sound. The Government has a large investment in Indian residential schools and the principals in charge of these institutions should be encouraged to operate them efficiently and to aim not at a low average attendance but at the highest average attendance possible.

I feel that the time has now arrived when we should provide from year to year the total amount required to operate our residential schools on the assumption that these schools will have an average attendance of pupils of approximately 95%. I am sending forward, for your information, memorandum submitted to me by the Superintendent of Welfare and Training, dated February 8, 1940. I am sending forward also a statement showing the authorized pupilage at each residential school during the year 1939 and the actual average pupilage during the same year. I should like to direct your attention particularly to the summary of this statement which reads as follows:

| Month | Total authorised pupilage at all residential schools | Total average attendance stall residential schools | Per cent of average to authorized pupilage |
|-------|------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| March 1939 | 8538 | 8250.05 | 96.63 |
| June 1939 | 8538 | 8308.48 | 97.32 |
| Sept. 1939 | 8538 | 8150.28 | 95.46 |
| Dec. 1939 | 8538 | 8275.44 | 96.96 |
In preparing the estimates for the present fiscal year (1940-41) the amount requested for per capita grants was $1,271,249.00. This sum represents 92.24% of the amount that would be required to make our per capita grant payments for the present fiscal year if our schools operated with their full quota of pupils and with an average attendance of approximately 100%.

From our experience in 1939 you will note that an additional amount will be necessary for the fiscal year 1940-41 as it is now apparent that the total average attendance will exceed by a substantial margin an average of 92.24%. In fact, for the year 1939 it averaged 96.59% and there is every reason to believe that it will be as much, if not more, during the current year. The Indian school population is increasing at the rate of approximately 300 per annum. This fact in itself must tend toward a higher enrolment at residential schools. The number of orphan and neglected children for whom provision must be made at these institutions appears to have increased steadily during the depression years.

In view of the fact that the payments for the quarter ended March 31, 1940, are now due, I am anxious that a decision should be reached at an early date with respect to the amounts that should be paid. The officials of the Treasury feel that they should have specific instructions with respect to the policy of the Government in this regard before any payments for the March quarter are actually made.

DEPUTY HEAD
To Principals of Indian Residential Schools:

For some years past the Department has only included in the annual estimates a percentage of the amount that would be required if all Indian residential schools in Canada had their full enrolment throughout the academic year. This policy was first adopted in the fiscal year 1933-34 at which time the average attendance at all Indian residential schools was only 92% of the authorized enrolment and, therefore, the amount voted was sufficient to meet per capita grant payments.

However, in the last two or three years practically all Indian residential schools have enrolled their full authorized number of pupils and in many cases have been carrying several pupils more than their authorized pupilage. As a result the average attendance at all Indian residential schools for the past year has greatly increased. On the other hand, despite the return last year of the 5% deduction, the percentage of the actual appropriation provided by Parliament remains the same. Consequently the amount provided for per capita grants will not permit our paying more than 92.24% of the authorized pupilage at any Indian residential school. I regret that this contingency has arisen but due to present conditions it is impossible to remedy it.

As the March quarter per capita grants are paid from the current year's appropriation it will be necessary to pay this on the basis of 92.24% of the authorized pupilage. You have already been forwarded approximately 50% of your earnings for the March quarter and a cheque for the balance that can be allowed will go forward within a week.

The Department will have no objection, as a temporary measure, if you can find it convenient, to your reducing your present enrolment to the percentage upon which per capita payments will be based.

To Principals of Indian Residential Schools:

For some years past the Department has only included in the annual estimates a percentage of the amount that would be required if all Indian residential schools in Canada had their full enrolment throughout the academic year. This policy was first adopted in the fiscal year 1933-34 at which time the average attendance at all Indian residential schools was only 92% of the authorized enrolment and, therefore, the amount voted was sufficient to meet per capita grant payments.

However, in the last two or three years practically all Indian residential schools have enrolled their full authorized number of pupils and in many cases have been carrying several pupils more than their authorized pupilage. As a result the average attendance at all Indian residential schools for the past year has greatly increased. On the other hand, despite the return last year of the 5% deduction, the percentage of the actual appropriation provided by Parliament remains the same. Consequently the amount provided for per capita grants will not permit our paying more than 92.24% of the authorized pupilage at any Indian residential school. I regret that this contingency has arisen but due to present conditions it is impossible to remedy it.

As the March quarter per capita grants are paid from the current year's appropriation it will be necessary to pay this on the basis of 92.24% of the authorized pupilage. You have already been forwarded approximately 80% of your earnings for the March quarter and a cheque for the balance that can be allowed will go forward within a week.

The Department will have no objection, as a temporary measure, if you can find it convenient, to your reducing your present enrolment to the percentage upon which per capita payments will be based.

Director.

Dear Dr. McGill:

The copy of your circular letter of the 22nd ultimo,
No. 1-1-3, addressed to Principals of Indian Residential
Schools, reached me some days ago, and I have been
endeavouring ever since to find some way of averting
the very serious consequences to our Society which the
decision of the Government set forth therein, will
inevitably bring.

Speaking for myself personally, although I am con-
vinced that the same view is held by every member of our
Society, I realize that the extreme gravity of the
European situation makes it impossible for the Church
Societies cooperating with your Department of Government
in Indian educational work, to ask for a reconsideration
of the latter's decision to reduce the per capita grants.

The reduction of the privilege to 92.24 per cent, as
suggested by you, would not make an appreciable difference
in the operating cost of any School, and when I point
out that our Society has now a bank overdraft of $35,586.00,
or which 44% must be paid, and that the reduction in the
per capita grant will mean a yearly loss in revenue of at
least $21,000.00, you will understand my profound concern
in the matter.

In my position as Secretary and Executive officer of
our Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission, I am
expected to suggest some way whereby our Indian Schools
may be kept in operation, and I now write for the specific purpose of ascertaining if your Department of Government could arrange for a certain number of the refugee children who are, I understand, to be brought to Canada in the near future, to be accommodated at some of our Schools on a per capita grant earning basis. If our Commission limited the Indian pupilage to the number you suggested in your circular, we would distribute among the Schools located near to the railway lines a total of one hundred of the refugees. The Schools I have in mind are as follows:

Chapleau ........ 10
Shingweau ....... 20
Sioux Lookout... 20
Elkhorn .......... 10
Blackfoot ....... 20
Blood ........... 15
Peigan .......... 5

I am assuming that the Government will be obliged to allocate a certain sum of money for the care of the refugees, and that the grant for any accommodated at our Schools would be provided from that special source and not from the approved estimates for your Department.

As the above suggestion is intended to help the Government as well as our Society, I will be interested to learn at your earliest convenience if there is any possibility of its being accepted.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

THW/KH
Ottawa, June 19, 1940.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 7, in which you submit, for departmental consideration, a suggestion that provision be made at a number of residential schools operated by the Government, in co-operation with your Commission, for the care of 100 refugee children.

I am not in a position at this date to state what provision is likely to be made by the Government for the care of refugee children in the Dominion. I am, however, sending forward your suggestion to the Minister for his consideration. Should the Government decide to make provision for the care of refugees at residential schools, I am disposed to think that they would be likely to take over one or two schools for this purpose rather than send small numbers of refugee children to a number of schools throughout the Dominion. However, this is just my personal opinion. I shall be glad to communicate with you again in respect to the matter when I am in a position to supply you with more definite information.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Director.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am attaching hereto copy of a circular letter sent out to the Principals of our Indian residential schools and dated Ottawa, May 26, 1940, and also copy of a reply received by me from Dr. T. H. R. Westgate, Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada.

I have acknowledged receipt of this letter and intimated to Dr. Westgate that I am sending forward to you for your consideration the suggestion made by him with respect to the care of refugee children at Indian residential schools.

You will note that the Anglican Residential School Commission have a bank overdraft at this date of $5,566. In addition to this, it is just possible that they are no longer able to secure funds from old country sources for missionary effort in this country. I am of the opinion, therefore, that they will experience the utmost difficulty in keeping their Indian residential schools open and in operation during the war period.

Should the Government decide to make provision for a number of refugee children at Indian residential schools, it would be advisable, in my judgment, to take over two or three residential schools and operate them for this purpose rather than send groups of children to a large number of our residential schools throughout the Dominion.

Director.

RAH
Ottawa,
August 6, 1940.

Additional amount needed for 6 combined schools in order to pay them on a ten-month basis .................. $265.00
The usual grant for Whitefish River has been paid for the months of April, May and June amounting to $300.00. Owing to small attendance of Indian children at this school the authorities have been advised that no further payments will be made to them. As $300.00 was voted for this school there will be an unexpended balance of $600.00.

Payment of $195.00 has been made to the Jack River C.E. School for the months of April, May and June. The amount not required at the Whitefish River Combined School will provide more than the amount required to pay for a ten-month term at the other 6 schools mentioned above.

I should appreciate receiving your concurrence in allowing the grant for a ten-month period during the academic year 1940-41 at the combined white and Indian schools.
